questions.text: Fructosamine (which is used for assessing long term glycemic control in a person with hemolysis) is a glycated product of: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Albumin

 

Fructosamine is a compound formed when glucose binds to serum albumin, which is the most abundant protein in the blood. This glycated product provides an indicator of long-term glycemic control because it reflects the average blood glucose levels over the previous 2 to 3 weeks. Since it is primarily formed from the glycation of albumin, option d (Albumin) is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycosaminoglycan refers to a different type of compound, glycosaminoglycans, which are long, linear polysaccharides found in connective tissues.

 

Option B. Urea is a waste product removed by the kidneys and is not involved in fructosamine formation.

 

Option C. Fructose is a sugar but is not directly related to the formation of fructosamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose can be attached to proteins, albumin, and also to RBCs forming HbA1c. Fructosamine is term used for all the glycated proteins including glycated albumin.

 

 

 

In hemolysis patient, HbA1c analysis cannot be done because it will be falsely decreased due to damage to RBCs and loss of hemoglobin. So, fructosamine determination is used for these patients.

questions.text: Match the following scale types with their lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

Matched Pairs:

 

  • 1-b: Collarette scales - Pityriasis Rosea: Collarette scales are characteristic of Pityriasis Rosea, where these scales are fine, peripherally attached but centrally detached, often found around the edge of the herald patch or subsequent lesions.
  • 2-c: Silvery scales - Psoriasis: Silvery scales are hallmark features of Psoriasis. These scales are typically seen as thick, shiny, and silvery white, indicative of excessive proliferation of skin layers, particularly due to parakeratosis.
  • 3-d: Mica-like scales - Pityriasis lichenoides chronica: Mica-like scales in Pityriasis lichenoides chronica refer to the fine, adherent scales that resemble mineral mica, found on polymorphic lesions that can also show hemorrhagic crusting.
  • 4-a: Branny scales - Pityriasis versicolor: Branny scales are a feature of Pityriasis versicolor, described as fine, powdery, and often easily detachable, much like bran. These scales highlight the superficial fungal infection's impact on the skin.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Diseases & special scales:

 

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 4.13, 26.2, 29.15, 40.1-40.5, 50.6, 65.2, 107.3, 109.8

questions.text: The viruses of the filoviridae family like Ebola and Marburg resemble which of the following morphologies? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3

 

  • Viruses belonging to the filoviridae family, such as Ebola and Marburg, resemble the morphology shown in image 3.
  • Image 3 - Ebola viruses are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Image 1- Influenza viruses have linear segmented, single-stranded RNA.

 

 

Image 2- Adenovirus is an icosahedroal symmetry with fibres extruding from vertices and contains double-stranded DNA.

 

 

Image 4 - Corona virus is non-segmented single-stranded RNA virus.

 

Coronavirus Structure

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Filoviruses, such as Ebola and Marburg, are filamentous and contain nonsegmented single-stranded RNA.

choices.text: Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis
Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with prostate cancer is being investigated. The bone scan is reported as a super scan with increased uptake in the bones and reduced activity in the kidney and soft tissue. What is the reason for this super scan appearance? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis

 

Explanation:

 

The super scan appearance is due to increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis.

 

On a bone scan, a generalized increase in skeletal uptake relative to soft tissue and absent or faint renal activity. This is referred to as a super scan.

 

 

  • All the bones show diffusely increased uptake whereas kidneys are not visualized.
  • Seen with-
    1. Metabolic bone diseases
    2. Diffuse Sclerotic bone metastasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased uptake by carcinoma prostate: While the primary prostate carcinoma may cause metastases, the increased uptake seen in a super scan specifically refers to bone metastases, not the primary tumor itself.

 

Option C. Increased uptake by the bone: This option is too general and does not specify the underlying cause, which in the context of a super scan is typically metastatic disease.

 

Option D. Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney: This choice misrepresents the scenario, as the decreased visualization of kidneys is a result of the intense skeletal uptake overshadowing other areas, not due to decreased uptake by these organs themselves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A bone scan super scan appearance in a patient with known malignancy such as prostate cancer usually indicates extensive bone metastasis, necessitating aggressive management and treatment planning to address widespread disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with cough, cold, fever, and malaise associated with weight loss and ascites. The patient does not have any evidence of cirrhosis and her coagulation profile is normal. Ascitic fluid analysis showed elevated adenosine deaminase. What can be done next? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start ATT

 

In countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis, such as India, the presence of elevated adenosine deaminase (ADA) in ascitic fluid is highly suggestive of abdominal tuberculosis (TB). ADA is a useful diagnostic marker for TB, particularly when its levels are significantly elevated (e.g., above 39 IU/L). Given the clinical context of weight loss, fever, and ascites, along with a high ADA level, it is reasonable to initiate anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) without further invasive testing. Starting ATT and monitoring the patient's response is an effective and practical approach, especially in resource-limited settings. This strategy avoids unnecessary invasive procedures like peritoneal biopsy, which should be reserved for cases where there is doubt about the diagnosis or if the patient does not respond to initial therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peritoneal Biopsy: While peritoneal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing peritoneal TB, it is invasive and resource-intensive. In high-prevalence areas, where elevated ADA levels strongly suggest TB, initiating ATT is preferred.

 

Option C. Observation: Given the significant clinical symptoms and elevated ADA levels, mere observation is not appropriate. Delay in treatment could lead to worsening of the patient’s condition.

 

Option D. Laparotomy: Laparotomy is an invasive surgical procedure and is not warranted for diagnosing TB when non-invasive methods like ADA testing and clinical presentation strongly suggest the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In high-prevalence countries for tuberculosis, elevated adenosine deaminase (ADA) in ascitic fluid, along with clinical signs, is sufficient to start anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) without the need for invasive procedures.

questions.text: The clinical finding in the 10-year-old boy includes fever, joint pain, and a hand lesion as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis based on these findings? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gottron's papules - Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

  • Juvenile dermatomyositis is a rare inflammatory disease affecting the skin and muscles. It typically presents in children with a characteristic skin rash and muscle weakness.
  • Gottron's papules are distinctive red or violet, raised, scaly lesions seen over knuckles (dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal joints), elbows, knees, and other extensor surfaces, highly suggestive of dermatomyositis.
  • The combination of fever, joint pain, and Gottron's papules strongly indicates juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Other features associated with Dermatomyositis are:

 

  • The Gottron's sign is a distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.

 

 

Gottron's sign: seen in the above image

 

  • Shawl sign or V-sign: Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution) as seen in the image below

 

 

  • Periungual telangiectasias: enlarged capillaries in the nail folds.

 

 

  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer.

 

 

  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid nodules - Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis:

 

  • Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder causing chronic joint inflammation in children.
  • Rheumatoid nodules are firm, painless, subcutaneous nodules that usually occur in areas of pressure but are not typically seen in the hands in this form.
  • The lesion in the image doesn't match the typical appearance of rheumatoid nodules.

 

Option C Sclerodactyly - Systemic sclerosis:

 

  • Systemic sclerosis is a connective tissue disease characterized by skin thickening and hardening (scleroderma).
  • Sclerodactyly refers to thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers and hands, leading to a claw-like appearance.
  • The lesion shown doesn't indicate the skin thickening or tightness characteristic of sclerodactyly.

 

Option D Mechanic's hand - Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • SLE is an autoimmune disease affecting multiple organ systems.
  • Mechanic's hand is a sign associated more with dermatomyositis than SLE, characterized by rough, cracked skin on the sides of the fingers, mimicking the hands of a manual labourer.
  • The presentation of mechanic's hand in SLE is less common and the symptoms described do not align well with SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case involving fever, joint pain, and hand lesions in a child, the presence of Gottron's papules is indicative of Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 53 page no 53.1-53.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page 2820-2821

questions.text:
Consider the following actions under AMTSL. Arrange them in the right order? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Uterine tone assessment
  2. Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 mg)
  3. Exclude the presence of another fetus
  4. Controlled cord traction

 

AMTSL- Active management of the third stage of labor.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 2, 4, 1

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) is a set of interventions aimed at preventing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). The correct order of actions is:

 

3. Exclude the presence of another fetus: Ensure there is no additional fetus before administering any uterotonic.

 

2. Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 mg): Administer a uterotonic drug to help the uterus contract and reduce bleeding. It is given after the delivery of baby.

 

4. Controlled cord traction: Perform controlled traction on the umbilical cord to deliver the placenta.

 

1. Uterine tone assessment: assess the uterine tone every 15 minutes to detect uterine atony.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steps of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) should be followed in a specific order: exclude the presence of another fetus, administer a uterotonic, perform controlled cord traction, and then assess the uterine tone.

questions.text:
Which of the following types of headaches requires further evaluation? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Headache for > 4 hours
  2. Worst headache of life
  3. New-onset progressive headache
  4. Headache with blurring of vision
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) 2, 3, 4

 

Certain types of headaches can be indicative of serious underlying conditions and thus require further evaluation to rule out life-threatening or severe pathologies:

 

2. Worst headache of life: This is a classic description of a subarachnoid hemorrhage, which is a medical emergency. Patients experiencing this type of headache require immediate medical attention and thorough investigation, typically involving neuroimaging.

 

3. New-onset progressive headache: Progressive headaches, especially those that are new in onset and occur in adults, raise concern for potential serious conditions such as brain tumors or other intracranial pathologies. These headaches warrant detailed medical evaluation.

 

4. Headache with blurring of vision: This symptom combination suggests possible increased intracranial pressure, which can be associated with conditions like papilledema or optic neuritis. Such cases need prompt assessment to determine the cause and appropriate management.

 

Other Option:

 

1. Headache for > 4 hours: While a headache lasting more than four hours can be distressing, it is not necessarily indicative of a severe underlying condition. Such headaches could be primary headaches like tension-type headaches or migraines, which often do not require immediate further evaluation unless they have other alarming features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Headaches described as the "worst headache of life," new-onset progressive headaches, and headaches accompanied by blurring of vision require further medical evaluation to rule out serious conditions.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs is a β2 agonist?

 

  1. Dopexamine
  2. Dipivefrine
  3. Fenoldopam
  4. Mirabegron
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2

 

Dipivefrine and dopexamine are β2-adrenergic receptor agonists.

 

  • Dipivefrine is a prodrug of epinephrine used to lower intraocular pressure in patients with open-angle glaucoma and ocular hypertension. It decreases aqueous humor production and enhances its outflow.
  • Dopexamine is a synthetic analogue of dopamine, which acts on D1 and D2 receptors and exhibits weak activity on β2 receptors. It is used in patients with severe heart failure, sepsis, and shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Fenoldopam (Option 3) is a selective D1 receptor agonist with moderate affinity for α2-adrenergic receptors. It is primarily used as a vasodilator in hypertensive emergencies and does not act as a β2 agonist.

 

Mirabegron (Option 4) is a β3-adrenergic receptor agonist used to treat overactive bladder by relaxing the detrusor muscle, increasing bladder capacity, and improving storage symptoms. It is not a β2 agonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dipivefrine and dopexamine are β2-adrenergic receptor agonists used in clinical settings for conditions such as glaucoma and heart failure, respectively. Recognizing drug-receptor interactions is essential for understanding their therapeutic applications.

questions.text: Combination of appearance in CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinovarus) is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Equinus, inversion, forefoot adduction, cavus

 

In congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), or idiopathic clubfoot, the deformity involves equinus, inversion, forefoot adduction, and cavus. CTEV is a congenital malformation of the foot and is predominantly seen in male children. The calf and medial foot tissues are underdeveloped.

 

Components of the deformity:

 

  1. Cavus: This deformity occurs due to exaggerated arching of the foot at the mid-tarsal joint.
  2. Adduction: This deformity occurs at the talonavicular joint.
  3. Inversion: This deformity occurs at the subtalar joint, where the calcaneus is inverted, leading to a medially facing sole.
  4. Equinus: This deformity occurs at the ankle joint and tarsal joints, causing plantar flexion.

 

The equinovarus deformity causes inward twisting of the foot, with the sole facing posteromedially in severe cases. Associated disorders like hip dislocation and spina bifida should be evaluated.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Ponseti's method is a successful manipulation technique for CTEV. It begins as early as the first 2 weeks after birth, involving weekly manipulation of the foot using plaster casts. Ponseti’s method follows the correction order: Cavus-adduction-varus-equinus (CAVE).
  • Typically, five casts are required for correction, followed by bracing to maintain the corrected position. Foot abduction brace (FAB) is used initially full-time and then at night for up to 4 years to prevent relapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Equinus, eversion, forefoot adduction, cavus: This option is incorrect as the deformity involves inversion, not eversion.

 

Option C. Equinus, eversion, forefoot abduction, cavus: This option is incorrect because forefoot adduction is the correct deformity pattern, not abduction, and inversion, not eversion.

 

Option D. Equinus, inversion, forefoot adduction, planus: While this option correctly includes equinus, inversion, and adduction, it incorrectly describes the foot as planus (flat). In CTEV, there is cavus, or an exaggerated arch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The deformity in Congenital Talipes Equinovarus (CTEV) consists of equinus, inversion, forefoot adduction, and cavus. Early detection and treatment using Ponseti’s method can correct the deformity and prevent long-term complications.

choices.text: 200 mL/hour

questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50 mL/hour

 

The normal insensible water loss is 50 mL/hour.

 

In human beings, there is a loss of water through vaporization from the respiratory tract (300–400 mL) and diffusion from the skin (300–400 mL). This is called insensible water loss. It is about 50 mL/hour. This insensible water loss via the skin is independent of sweating and occurs in people without sweat glands as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 100 mL/hour: 100 mL/hour is incorrect. The normal insensible water loss is 50 mL/hour, not 100 mL/hour.

 

Option B. 150 mL/hour: 150 mL/hour is incorrect. Insensible water loss is less, typically around 50 mL/hour.

 

Option D. 200 mL/hour: 200 mL/hour is incorrect. This value is too high for normal insensible water loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insensible water loss is the loss of water through vaporization from the respiratory tract and diffusion from the skin, which accounts for approximately 50 mL/hour in humans.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache. He has a history of thorn prick injury a week back. What antibiotics would you give empirically to this child? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amoxicilin +clavulanate

 

The symptoms described in this case—fever, rash, sore throat, and body aches—following a thorn prick injury suggest the possibility of scarlet fever caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS). Scarlet fever typically presents with a diffuse erythematous rash, which may be papular, along with other symptoms such as a sore throat, body aches, and the characteristic "strawberry tongue."

 

Key Points:

 

  • Scarlet Fever and GAS: Scarlet fever is most commonly caused by GAS and is characterized by the production of pyrogenic (erythrogenic) exotoxin, leading to the rash and other systemic symptoms.
  • Empirical Antibiotic Treatment:
    • Amoxicillin + Clavulanate: This combination is a first-line treatment for infections caused by GAS, particularly when there is a concern for beta-lactamase-producing bacteria. Clavulanate inhibits beta-lactamase enzymes, allowing amoxicillin to remain effective against the bacteria.
    • Penicillin or Amoxicillin alone is generally the treatment of choice for scarlet fever, but adding clavulanate broadens the spectrum to cover potential mixed infections.
  • Diagnostic Confirmation: While empirical treatment is initiated, a rapid antigen detection test or throat culture for Streptococcus should be performed to confirm the diagnosis of GAS infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is typically reserved for more severe infections requiring hospitalization. It is not the first choice for uncomplicated scarlet fever.

 

Option C. Vancomycin. and Option D. Meropenem: These are higher-tier antibiotics reserved for severe or resistant infections, often guided by culture and sensitivity results. They are not typically used as first-line treatment in cases of suspected scarlet fever or mild GAS infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a child presenting with symptoms suggestive of scarlet fever following a thorn prick injury, empirical antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin + clavulanate is appropriate while awaiting diagnostic confirmation of Group A Streptococcus infection.

questions.text: In a diabetic patient, the following lesions are present in the armpit. What would be observed during a Wood's lamp examination? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coral red fluorescence.

 

  • The clinical scenario of a diabetic patient, along with the observed hyperpigmented lesion in axilla strongly suggests erythrasma.
  • Coral-red fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination is the characteristic finding in this disease.

 

 

Erythrasma

 

  • It is a skin infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. This condition is commonly seen in individuals with diabetes and weakened immune systems and is associated with factors such as obesity, excessive sweating, and poor hygiene.
  • The characteristic feature of erythrasma is the presence of hyperpigmented patches that are typically asymptomatic. These patches commonly appear in areas like the axilla, groin, intergluteal, and sub-mammary regions.
  • The coral pink fluorescence observed during Wood's lamp examination is a defining feature of erythrasma and is caused by coproporphyrin III, a pigment produced by the bacterium.

 

 

  • Wood's lamp uses ultraviolet wavelength light at 365nm (320-400nm) with a peak at 365nm. The filter of the Wood's lamp is composed of Barium silicate and 9% Nickel oxide.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Yellow fluorescence: Often seen with Pityriasis versicolor, which fluoresces yellow or apple green due to the presence of tryptophan metabolites produced by Malassezia species.

 

Option C. Blue fluorescence: Not commonly associated with bacterial or fungal infections of the skin but may appear in certain conditions unrelated to common skin infections.

 

Option D. Green fluorescence: Typically observed with Pseudomonas infections or some cases of Tinea capitis caused by fungi that produce substances that fluoresce green.

 

Additional Information

 

Table: Various diseases & their colour on woods lamp examination

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Wood's lamp uses UVA light with a wavelength of 365nm (320-400 nm) for the diagnosis of various skin conditions based on the fluorescence characteristics of the skin under this specific range of ultraviolet light.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.20

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 26 Page no 26.40
