questions.text: What of the following stain can be used for staining Iron in tissues? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prussian blue  

 

Perl's iron stain is the classic method for demonstrating iron in tissues. The section is treated with dilute hydrochloric acid to release ferric ions from binding proteins. These ions then react with potassium ferrocyanide to produce an insoluble blue compound (the Prussian blue reaction).

 

 

Used in hereditary hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue, lead toxicity to visualize iron-laden mitochondria of ring sideroblasts and myelodysplastic syndrome.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Masson's trichrome: This stain is used to differentiate between collagen and other tissue components. It stains collagen fibers blue or green, muscle fibers red, and cytoplasm light red or pink. It is not used for detecting iron.

 

Option C. PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff): PAS stain is primarily used to detect glycogen and other polysaccharides in tissues. It stains these components magenta. PAS is not useful for detecting iron in tissues.

 

Option D. Fite-Faraco: This is a special stain used for detecting Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium responsible for leprosy. It is not used for staining iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prussian blue stain is specifically used for detecting iron deposits in tissues, particularly in cases of iron overload or iron-related disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following rules of law are associated with insanity? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both A and B

 

Durham's rule and Curren's rule are laws associated with insanity.

 

  • Curren's rule of 1964 states that an accused person is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law, as a result of mental disease or defect.
  • Durham 's rule of 1954 States that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both Durham's rule and Curren's rule are significant tests used to determine criminal responsibility in cases where the defendant's mental state is in question.

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of human immunodeficiency virus. Which of the following drugs acts at step 5? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Raltegravir


The step 5 in the given image shows the step of integration of the viral genome into the host DNA with the help of Integrase enzyme. Among the above given drugs, Raltegravir can be used to block this step as it is an integrase inhibitor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enfuvirtide: It is fusion inhibitor, which acts by binding to gp41 protein on the surface of the virus. This inhibits the Step 1 of this diagram.

 

Option C. Tenofovir & Option D) Zidovudine: These are NRTIs which are used in combination therapy against HIV virus. NRTI works by inhibiting the activity of reverse transcriptase (Step 6 of the diagram), thereby, preventing the viral replication.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the tumor shown in the radiograph? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epiphyseal

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma):

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology:
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Radiological features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30% malignant transformation. This is incorrect. Pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.

 

Option C. Ground glass opacity is diagnostic. This is incorrect. Ground glass opacity of the bone is seen in fibrous dysplasia.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy is the treatment. This is incorrect. The mainstay of treatment of GCT is curettage and stripping of the cavity. More aggressive tumors are treated by excision and bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant cell tumors are epiphyseal tumors of the long bones.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by the presence of specific tumors and physical features. This syndrome is often referred to as "Triple M syndrome" because it commonly presents with three key features: mucosal neuromas, a marfanoid body habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma. In addition, pheochromocytomas may also occur.

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer originating from the parafollicular cells (C cells) that produce calcitonin. MTC is a hallmark of MEN 2B, making it one of the primary diagnostic criteria for the syndrome.

 

The condition is associated with mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, specifically the codon 918 mutation on chromosome 10, which leads to the development of these tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Café au lait spot: Café au lait spots are not characteristic of MEN 2B syndrome. These pigmented skin lesions are more commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and, in some cases, tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C. Parathyroid adenoma: Parathyroid adenomas are typically seen in patients with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, not in MEN 2B. These adenomas cause hyperparathyroidism, which is not a feature of MEN 2B.

 

Option D. Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve gliomas are primarily associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). They are not a feature of MEN 2B syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most significant feature of MEN 2B syndrome is the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma, alongside mucosal neuromas and a marfanoid body habitus, often linked to mutations in the RET proto-oncogene

choices.text: In the axillary pad of fat, at the apex of the axilla
Along the margin of the pectoralis minor

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a breast lump and the physician suspects breast cancer. The physician orders imaging studies and a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. During the diagnostic workup, the physician explains the lymphatic drainage of the breast and discusses the location of the apical lymph nodes. In which location are the apical lymph nodes located?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. In the axillary pad of fat, at the apex of the axilla.

The lymphatic drainage from the breast is mostly drained into the axillary lymph nodes. The axillary lymph nodes are divided into five groups, and the apical group of axillary lymph nodes is located at the apex of the axilla. The apical lymph nodes are present partly above the superior margin of the pectoralis minor and partly posterior to the superior part of the muscle. They are present along the axillary vessels. The other four groups of axillary lymph nodes are lateral/humeral, anterior/pectoral, posterior/subscapular, and central. Understanding the location and distribution of axillary lymph nodes is important in the diagnosis and management of breast cancer.

questions.text: Fibres of the given structure originate from? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

The given structure is the fornix and its fibres arise from the hippocampus.

 

The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter fibers that connects the hippocampus to other regions of the brain, including the mammillary bodies, thalamus, and septal nuclei. The fibers of the fornix arise from the hippocampus, which is involved in the formation and consolidation of memories, and then project through the fornix to other parts of the limbic system. Dysfunction of the fornix and hippocampus can result in memory impairments, as seen in conditions such as Alzheimer's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amygdala: The amygdala is a small almond-shaped structure located deep within the temporal lobes of the brain. It is involved in processing emotions, especially fear and emotional memory. While the amygdala does have connections to the limbic system, it is not a direct source of fibers for the fornix. However, it does interact with the hippocampus and other limbic structures.

 

Option B. Mammillary Body: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, round structures located on the undersurface of the brain, specifically in the diencephalon. They are closely connected to the hippocampus and are considered part of the limbic system. The fornix sends fibers to and receives fibers from the mammillary bodies, facilitating the flow of information within the limbic circuit.

 

Option C. Caudate Nucleus: The caudate nucleus is a component of the basal ganglia and is involved in motor control and cognitive functions. While it interacts with some limbic structures, it is not a primary source of fornix fibers. Instead, it has connections with other regions involved in motor control and reward processing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hippocampus is a critical structure within the limbic system that plays a central role in memory formation and spatial navigation. It is the primary source of fibers that make up the fornix. The fornix carries information from the hippocampus to other limbic structures, including the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nuclei, as well as to the septal nuclei and the cingulate gyrus.

choices.text: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done.
High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used.
It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.
Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement in rapid sequence intubation? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.


Incorrect statement. Rapid sequence intubation typically involves administering an induction agent and a neuromuscular blocking agent to facilitate endotracheal intubation without the risk of aspiration. However, in cardiac arrest patients, the priority is to secure the airway quickly without delay. Often, these patients do not require medications for intubation as they are unresponsive and without protective reflexes. Also, chest compressions and defibrillation (if indicated) are of higher priority.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done:
Correct statement. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen before RSI helps to denitrogenate the lungs, ensuring that the patient has an adequate oxygen reserve during the apneic period (the time between paralysis and successful intubation). The goal is to delay the onset of hypoxemia during the apnea.

 

Option B. High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used:
Correct statement. A high-volume low-pressure cuff on the endotracheal tube distributes the pressure over a larger area of the tracheal mucosa. This minimizes the risk of tracheal injury or necrosis.

 

Option D. Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously:
Correct statement. In RSI, immediately after administering the induction agent (to render the patient unconscious), a neuromuscular blocking agent (muscle relaxant) is given to paralyze the patient, thus facilitating endotracheal intubation. This rapid administration of drugs is to minimize the time between loss of protective reflexes and securing the airway, hence reducing the risk of aspiration.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Rapid sequence intubation is not the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients due to the need for immediate airway management and ongoing chest compressions, making drug administration less critical.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presented in OPD with complaints of fatigue and weakness. Investigations revealed the following as shown below. The peripheral smear is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Hb – 5 g%

 

MCH – 24

 

MCV – Low

 

TLC – 11000 /µL

 

Platelets – 5,00,000 /cubic mm

 

Normal values:

 

  • Mean cell volume (MCV): 90 +/- 8 fL
  • Mean cell Hb (MCH): 30 +/- 3 pg
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron-deficiency anemia

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of microcytic hypochromic anemia for which the most common cause is Iron Deficiency Anemia.

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by:

 

  • Low serum ferritin: Reflects low iron stores.
  • Low serum iron: Indicates a lack of available iron.
  • High TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity): Reflects the body’s increased capacity to bind iron, which happens when iron levels are low.
  • Low transferrin saturation: Reflects low iron availability relative to the binding capacity.

 

These findings together with the low MCV, low MCH, low Hb and compensatory increase in the platelets strongly suggest iron deficiency anemia rather than other conditions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Megaloblastic anemia: Typically presents with macrocytic anemia (high MCV), which is not the case here. Also, MCH would generally be elevated in megaloblastic anemia.

 

Option C. Thalassemia major: This condition would also present with microcytic anemia, but it typically does not show such severe hypochromia or the thrombocytosis seen in this case. Additionally, the Mentzer index (MCV/RBC count) is typically less than 13 in thalassemia trait, not in severe iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option D. Essential thrombocytosis: While this condition does present with an elevated platelet count, it does not typically present with the microcytic, hypochromic anemia seen in iron deficiency anemia. The primary abnormality in essential thrombocytosis is the elevated platelet count, without the severe anemia observed here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: MRI to rule out enlarged heart

questions.text: The parents notice that their child is tired and that he has shortness of breath on climbing stairs and while lying down. What is the first investigation that you would do? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest x-ray

 

The first investigation to be done for a child who feels shortness of breath on climbing stairs and in the supine position is a chest x-ray.

 

The child having shortness of breath on dyspnea on exertion worsened in the supine position is orthopnea could be suggestive of congestive heart failure.

 

Causes -

 

  1. Respiratory causes include asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD), pneumonia, and pulmonary embolism.
  2. Cardiovascular causes include congestive heart failure (CH), pulmonary edema, valvular heart defect, and pulmonary hypertension.

 

Evaluation

 

  • Oxygen saturation at rest and during physical activity
  • Chest x-ray is the first diagnostic test as pulmonary pathology or pulmonary edema and signs of CHF may be seen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: An echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac cause if the chest X-ray is abnormal

 

Option C: Spirometry to assess lung function when the chest x-ray is normal.

 

Option D: Cardiac MRI (Magnetic resonance imaging) is an emerging modality done to look for cardiomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a child presenting with shortness of breath on exertion and orthopnea, the first investigation should be a chest x-ray to evaluate potential pulmonary pathology and signs of congestive heart failure.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman presented with total ophthalmoplegia, pulsatile proptosis of the right eye, retroorbital pain accompanied with fever and headache. On examination, fundus and BP were normal. Which of the following structures are involved?

 

  1. Abducens nerve
  2. Oculomotor nerve
  3. Internal carotid artery
  4. Cavernous sinus
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The clinical presentation of pulsatile proptosis, retroorbital pain, fever, and headache in a pregnant woman suggests the involvement of multiple cranial structures, primarily those associated with the cavernous sinus, a critical venous sinus at the base of the brain that acts as a conduit for venous blood drainage from the brain and eye. This constellation of symptoms and signs is indicative of cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST), a severe and potentially life-threatening condition.

 

  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a septic thrombus formed in the cavernous sinus due to the spread of infection from sinuses, teeth, ears, nose, and skin of the face.
  • Symptoms include fever, severe headache, supraorbital pain, seizures, and edema in the mastoid region.
  • Eye signs include proptosis, chemosis, and diplopia due to ophthalmoplegia from the involvement of oculomotor (CN-III), trochlear (CN-IV), and abducens nerve (CN-VI).
  • Absence of corneal sensation due to the involvement of the ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve (CN-V1)
  • Ipsilateral ptosis, dilated pupil, and absence of direct and consensual pupillary right reflex due to oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • Pulsatile proptosis occurs with the involvement of the internal carotid artery.
  • Brain magnetic resonance imaging or magnetic resonance venography should be done urgently for diagnosis.
  • Management of CST includes intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics, analgesics, anti-inflammatory drugs, and anticoagulants.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: For which medical condition is the provided drug typically recommended? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malaria

 

The picture depicts artemisin-based combination therapy (ACT). This medicine is used to treat falciparum malaria.

 

ARTEMISINS - Artesunate and Artemether

 

  • Fastest acting anti-malarial
  • Effective against MDR parasites
  • Short acting
  • C/I in 1st trimester

 

Artemisin Combination Therapy [ACT]

 

  • Artemisin + Long acting drug
  • DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria Combinations
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North Eastern States
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine: DOC for rest of India
  • The dose of artesunate is 200 mg OD for 3 days whereas sulfadoxine (1500 mg) and pyrimethamine (75 mg) should be taken on day 1 only

 

Educational Objective:

 

Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT), is typically recommended for the treatment of falciparum malaria.

choices.text: Loss of taste sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue
Loss of taste sensation in posterior 1/3rd of tongue
Loss of general sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue
Loss of motor sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue

questions.text: Fracture of the jugular canal can present as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of taste sensation in posterior 1/3rd of tongue

 

Fracture of the jugular canal affects the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) and presents as a loss of taste sensation in the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue.

 

  • The lingual nerve, which is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, gives general sensation to the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. The chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve gives taste sensation to the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue.
  • Both taste and general sensation of the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue are provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve.
  • The muscles of the tongue, with the exception of the palatoglossus, are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. The palatoglossus is supplied by the pharyngeal plexus.

 

The other nerves passing through the jugular foramen are the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) and the accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI), which may also be involved in cases of jugular canal fracture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loss of taste sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue: This sensation is mediated by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve. A fracture of the jugular canal would not affect this part of the tongue.

 

Option C. Loss of general sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue: This is mediated by the lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3), which is not involved in jugular canal fractures.

 

Option D. Loss of motor sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue: Motor innervation of the tongue is supplied by the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII), which is not affected by jugular canal fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fracture of the jugular canal can lead to a loss of taste sensation in the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue due to damage to the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX).

questions.text: Which of the following has been reported to have endemic transmission in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is caused by the nairovirus and has been reported to have endemic transmission in India. An outbreak was identified in Gujarat in 2011, and antibodies against the virus have been found in both human and animal sera in India. CCHF is primarily transmitted by Hyalomma ticks and is associated with a high mortality rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow fever: Yellow fever is primarily found in tropical and subtropical areas of South America and Africa and is caused by the flavivirus. It is not endemic to India. In urban settings, the disease is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes.

 

Option C. Ebola: Ebola virus causes hemorrhagic fever and was first reported in Sudan and Zaire. It has caused several outbreaks in West Africa, but there has been no endemic transmission of Ebola in India.

 

Option D. Hendra virus: Hendra virus is primarily a zoonotic disease that affects horses and was first identified in Australia. It is not known to have any transmission in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has endemic transmission in India, with the first outbreak reported in Gujarat in 2011. It is transmitted by Hyalomma ticks and has a high mortality rate.

questions.text: A patient with a history of fever, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and laboratory test result of leptospira IM reactivity, now presented with breathlessness, fever, and jaundice that worsened after treatment with penicillin. What is the possible diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction

 

The possible diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction.

 

The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR) is a transient clinical phenomenon that occurs in patients infected by spirochetes who undergo antibiotic treatment. The reaction typically occurs within 24 hours of starting antibiotic treatment for spirochete infections, including syphilis, leptospirosis, Lyme disease, and relapsing fever.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • The breakdown of the spirochetes after antibiotic administration releases endotoxins and cytokines into the bloodstream.
  • This causes an acute inflammatory reaction, characterized by the release of inflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-6 (IL-6), interleukin-8 (IL-8), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha).

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Symptoms include fever, chills, rigors, myalgia, headache, tachycardia, hyperventilation, and exacerbation of skin lesions.
  • The symptoms usually begin within 2 hours of antibiotic administration and resolve within 24 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resistant leptospirosis: This would present with ongoing symptoms despite appropriate antibiotic treatment, but not typically with acute worsening immediately after starting treatment.

 

Option B. Penicillin allergy: This would typically present with urticaria, pruritus, rash, or anaphylaxis, not with the acute inflammatory symptoms described.

 

Option C. Co-infection with dengue: This would be considered if there were signs and symptoms consistent with dengue, such as high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and hemorrhagic manifestations, but it does not explain the acute worsening after penicillin treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is an acute inflammatory response occurring within 24 hours of initiating antibiotic treatment for spirochete infections, characterized by fever, chills, myalgia, and exacerbation of symptoms due to the release of inflammatory cytokines.

choices.text: It is a dematiaceous fungus
Infection can spread and involve underlying subcutaneous tissue, tendon, muscle or joints
Angioinvasion is common especially in people with hemolytic anemia
These bodies are formed by engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages

questions.text: A forest worker developed skin lesions over the forearm, which initially started as macules but then became nodules. Histology of the nodules shows the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a dematiaceous fungus

 

  • Chromoblastomycosis (CBM) is defined as a chronic cutaneous and subcutaneous fungal infection resulting from traumatic implantation of certain dematiaceous fungi through the skin.
  • The most frequent aetiological agents of CBM are the following species: Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Phialophora verrucosa and Cladophialophora carrionii.
  • The aetiological agents gain entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds, usually by parts of plants.
  • In a typical manifestation the dermal lesions form cauliflower-like nodules. In the infected tissue, characteristic dark-colored, thick-walled, muriform cells i.e. sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) are observed, which is a histopathological criterion for the diagnosis.
  • The aetiological agent (i.e. fungal fragment) gains entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. Cases of buttock, trunk and face infection have also been reported. In more advanced stages of the disease dissemination may occur in the form of satellite lesions which arise from scratching autoinoculation and spread via the lymphatic system.
  • Treatment – Antifungal therapy with itraconazole or terbinafine. Surgical excision is the therapy of choice for small lesions.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Infection can spread and involve underlying subcutaneous tissue, tendon, muscle, or joints: This statement is more characteristic of eumycetoma, not chromoblastomycosis. Eumycetoma, caused by various fungal species, can invade deeper tissues including bone, leading to severe deformities.

 

Option C. Angioinvasion is common especially in people with hemolytic anemia: Angioinvasion is typically seen in infections caused by Aspergillus species, which can lead to invasive aspergillosis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. This is not a feature of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option D. These bodies are formed by the engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages: The bodies seen in the histological image (Medlar bodies) are not formed by macrophage engulfment. They are a morphological form of the fungi present in the infected tissue, indicative of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection characterized by the presence of dark-coloured, thick-walled sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) in histological sections, resulting from traumatic implantation of dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with multiple stab injuries to the chest. On examination, there is reduced chest movement on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left side. Additionally, the neck veins are distended. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Needle thoracocentesis

 

Patient with stab to chest with reduced chest movement on right, mediastinal shift to left with distended neck veins is suffering from tension pneumothorax. Next step is placement of wide bore needle in triangle of safety to decompress the pneumothorax, followed by ICD insertion.

 

This is the correct answer. Needle thoracocentesis is the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. It is a procedure that involves inserting a needle into the pleural space to aspirate the air or fluid. It is performed initially to decompress the tension pneumothorax in the triangle of safety (between Pect. Major anteriorly, Latissimus dorsi posteriorly, 5th intercostal space inferiorly).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency room thoracotomy: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. Resuscitative thoracotomy is an emergency surgical procedure that is performed in the presence of cardiac arrest due to penetrating chest trauma.

 

Option B. ICD placement: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. An ICD (intercostal drainage) is a tube inserted into the pleural space to drain the air or fluid. ICD placement is the definitive management of tension pneumothorax but is not the next step in the management.

 

Option D. Finger thoracotomy: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. Finger thoracotomy is an alternative approach when needle decompression fails or is not possible. It involves making a small incision in the chest wall and using the finger to manually decompress the pneumothorax. However, needle decompression should be attempted first before considering finger thoracostomy.

questions.text: What is the postmortem sign in which a gas shadow is present in the great vessels of a fetus in the case of intrauterine demise? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Robert‘s sign

 

Robert sign refers to the presence of a gas shadow within the heart or the greater vessels, in cases of fetal death in utero. It is a rare sign caused by postmortem blood degeneration, usually seen 1-2 days after death; and may be seen as early as 12 hours.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Spalding sign – overlapping of the fetal skull bones caused by collapse of the fetal brain.

 

Option C. Ball sign - hyperflexion of the spine with crowding of ribs seen in intrauterine death.

 

Option D. Halo sign - increase in soft tissue width between subcutaneous fat and the cranial vault.

 

Educational objective

 

Roberts sign is characterized by the presence of gas shadows in the heart or great vessels of a fetus, indicating intrauterine demise and typically appearing 1-2 days postmortem.

questions.text:
A woman presents at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following signs can be elicited at this gestation? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Goodell's sign
  2. Osiander's sign
  3. Internal ballottement
  4. Lightening
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

  • Goodell's sign: This sign is the softening of the cervix, which can be elicited around the 6th week of gestation.
  • Osiander's sign: This sign refers to the increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices, which can be detected between 6 to 8 weeks of gestation.
  • Internal ballottement: This can be elicited between the 16th and 28th weeks of gestation when the fetus can be felt to move away and return to the fingers upon gentle tap on the cervix.
  • Lightening: This is a sensation of relief of the pressure symptoms due to the engagement of the presenting part, typically felt around 38 weeks of gestation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 1, 3: Internal ballottement cannot be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation as it is typically felt between 16 and 28 weeks.

 

Option C. 1, 4: Lightening is not experienced until about 38 weeks of gestation, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. 3, 4: Neither internal ballottement nor lightening can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signs that can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation are Goodell's sign (softening of the cervix) and Osiander's sign (increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices).

 

  • Signs in early pregnancy are as shown below

 

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 74

choices.text: Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes

questions.text: Mode of transmission of abdominal TB includes all except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Direct contact with infected animal

 

Direct contact with infected animal is not a known mode of transmission for abdominal TB. Tuberculosis is primarily transmitted via inhalation of airborne droplets from a person with active pulmonary TB. While ingestion of Mycobacterium bovis from unpasteurized milk can lead to abdominal TB, Making it a feco-oral route of spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes: This occurs when TB bacteria spread directly from the mesenteric lymph nodes to the intestines. This form of spread is relatively common in abdominal TB.

 

Option C. Feco-oral route: Ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (from contaminated sputum or unpasteurized milk with M. bovis) can lead to intestinal TB.

 

Option D. Direct contact with infected animal: This is less common but can occur in cases where humans come into contact with animals infected with Mycobacterium bovis, a zoonotic strain of TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Modes of spread:

 

  1. By ingesting
    1. Infected food or milk - Primary intestinal tuberculosis
    2. Infected sputum - Secondary intestinal tuberculosis
  2. Hematogenous spread from distant tubercular focus
  3. Contagious spread from infected adjacent foci
  4. Through lymphatic channel
  5. Common site of abdominal TB - Terminal ileum and cecum

 

Feco-oral route is not known to spread abdominal TB.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented in OPD with a swelling in his neck. Given below is the histopathological image. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medullary carcinoma of thyroid

 

The histopathological image shows Amyloid deposition and nests of polygonal cells, which is suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid. This type of cancer is associated with the presence of amyloid deposits, which can be seen as pinkish extracellular material in the histological sections. These amyloid deposits are derived from calcitonin produced by the neoplastic C-cells (parafollicular cells).

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a neuroendocrine tumor that arises from the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland, which produce calcitonin. The histopathological hallmark of MTC is the presence of amyloid stroma, often stained with Congo red, showing apple-green birefringence under polarized light. Additionally, the tumor cells are often arranged in nests or sheets, with polygonal or spindle-shaped cells.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid: Characterized by the formation of papillae and distinct nuclear features like Orphan-Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and pseudoinclusions. It typically does not have amyloid deposition.

 

Option C. Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid: Typically shows follicles filled with colloid, and Hurthle cells may be present. This type is also known for hematogenous spread rather than lymphatic spread.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid: A highly aggressive form of thyroid cancer, characterized by pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells, and a lack of differentiated features seen in other thyroid carcinomas. It also lacks the amyloid deposits seen in medullary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with a satellite skin lesion. On examination, the patient has one hypopigmented lesion and one thickened nerve. The images of two blister packs are provided. Based on the WHO / NLEP Guidelines, which treatment is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer:

The correct answer is B. Packet 2 for 12 months.

Latest Guidelines for Leprosy: NLEP = WHO (from April 1, 2025)

As of April 1, 2025, India's NLEP has aligned completely with WHO guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of leprosy. This means that the same criteria and drug regimens are now followed globally and in India.

 

*If a case has any one of the three features suggestive of MB, he/she is classified as MB.

 

Treatment Regimen: WHO & NLEP (Post April 1st 2025)

 

Other Options:

Option A: Packet 1 for 12 months: 

This packet was used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy according to old guidelines of NLEP, which is not suitable for a patient with multibacillary leprosy.

Option C: Packet 1 for 6 months: 

This packet was used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy according to old guidelines of NLEP, which is not suitable for a patient with multibacillary leprosy.

Option D Packet 2 for 6 months: 

Although Packet 2 contains the correct medications, the treatment duration of 6 months is insufficient for multibacillary leprosy according to WHO guidelines, which recommends 12 months.

 

OLD NLEP GUIDELINES to diagnose Leprosy 

OLD NLEP GUIDELINES to treat Leprosy 

OLD PB MDT with 2 drugs followed by NLEP:

 

Educational objective:

  • As of April 1, 2025, NLEP follows WHO guidelines for both diagnosis and treatment.
  • Classification is based on skin lesions, nerve involvement, and skin smear.
  • For a patient with multibacillary leprosy, characterized by one or more thickened nerves and multiple skin lesions, the appropriate treatment is with a regimen containing rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone (Packet 2) for a duration of 12 months.

 

References:

Jopling’s handbook of leprosy, 6th edition, page no 10

Andrew’s diseases of the skin: clinical dermatology 13th edition page no 338, 339, 345

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The peripheral smear done is as shown below, and the Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What are the investigations to be done in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)
  2. PT and APTT
  3. Bone marrow
  4. Peripheral blood smear
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 4

 

The clinical presentation, along with the findings of the peripheral blood smear and a Mentzer index of less than 13, suggests a diagnosis of thalassemia.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thalassemia: A hemoglobinopathy characterized by a deficiency in the synthesis of one of the globin chains, either alpha or beta. In beta-thalassemia, there is reduced synthesis of beta chains, leading to decreased levels of hemoglobin A (HbA) and increased levels of HbA2 and HbF.
  • High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC): This test is crucial for diagnosing thalassemia as it can detect changes in hemoglobin levels, specifically the increased levels of HbA2 and HbF that are characteristic of beta-thalassemia. HPLC is sufficient for diagnosis without the need for bone marrow investigations.
  • Peripheral Blood Smear: The smear may reveal aniso-poikilocytosis, target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells, which are indicative of thalassemia.
  • Mentzer Index: The Mentzer index, calculated as MCV/RBC count, helps differentiate thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia. A value of less than 13 suggests thalassemia, while a value greater than 13 suggests iron-deficiency anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

2 (PT and APTT): These tests are not directly relevant for the diagnosis of thalassemia. PT (Prothrombin Time) is used to assess the extrinsic pathway of coagulation, and APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) assesses the intrinsic pathway, typically done when bleeding disorders are suspected.

 

3 (Bone Marrow): Bone marrow examination is not necessary in this case as the diagnosis of thalassemia can be made based on HPLC and peripheral smear findings. Bone marrow investigations are more appropriate for cases of pancytopenia or unexplained anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child suspected of having thalassemia, High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and a peripheral blood smear are key investigations for diagnosis.

choices.text: Rickettsia rickettsii
Rickettsia conorii
Ehrlichia chaffeensis

questions.text: Image of Rickettsial morula in a monocyte is shown below. Identify the organism? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ehrlichia chaffeensis

 

Ehrlichia chaffeensis is an obligate intracellular, Gram-negative species of Rickettsiales bacteria. It is a zoonotic pathogen transmitted to humans by the lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum) and is the causative agent of human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME).

 

Ehrlichiosis is evidenced by the presence of intracytoplasmic inclusions known as morulae in monocytes, which can be observed on a Giemsa-stained blood film.

 

Characteristics and Clinical Presentation:

 

  • Transmission: By the lone star tick (Amblyomma americanum).
  • Symptoms: Patients typically exhibit symptoms within 1 to 2 weeks after tick infection. Early symptoms include fever, headache, malaise, low-back pain, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Some patients may also have myalgias, arthralgias, coughing, pharyngitis, diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and changes in mental status.
  • Diagnosis: Besides observing morulae in monocytes, serological tests like indirect fluorescent antibody tests and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are also used for diagnosis.
  • Treatment: TOC Doxycycline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia rickettsii: Incorrect. Rickettsia rickettsii is the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), typically associated with rash and vascular endothelial damage, not morulae in monocytes.

 

Option B. Rickettsia conorii: Incorrect. Rickettsia conorii causes Mediterranean spotted fever, which also does not present with morulae in monocytes.

 

Option D. Anaplasma: Incorrect. Anaplasma phagocytophilum causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA), where morulae are found in granulocytes, not monocytes. The presence of morulae in granulocytes is characteristic of Anaplasma infection.

 

Educational objective:

 

Ehrlichia chaffeensis is identified by the presence of morulae in monocytes and is the causative agent of human monocytic ehrlichiosis. The proper treatment is doxycycline, and diagnosis is confirmed through blood smear, serological tests, and PCR.

 

GAME – Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis

questions.text: Match the given cellular components with their respective marker enzymes.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C

 

The correctly matched answer is 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C.

 

Each organelle has specific enzymes that act as marker enzymes, which are used to identify them after centrifugation in laboratory settings.

 

  • Mitochondria: ATP synthase (D) is a key enzyme of mitochondria involved in the production of ATP during oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Peroxisomes: Catalase (A) is the enzyme that breaks down hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) into water and oxygen, a primary function of peroxisomes.
  • Golgi complex: Galactosyl transferase (B) is associated with the Golgi complex and is involved in glycosylation, the process of adding sugar residues to proteins and lipids.
  • Endoplasmic reticulum: Glucose-6-phosphatase (C) is an enzyme located in the endoplasmic reticulum, crucial for glucose homeostasis and the final step in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misplaces the enzymes, associating ATP synthase with the wrong organelle (ER), and Catalase with Golgi instead of peroxisomes.

 

Option C. Incorrect pairing of glucose-6-phosphatase with mitochondria and galactosyl transferase with peroxisomes.

 

Option D. Incorrectly matches enzymes, such as pairing ATP synthase with the ER and glucose-6-phosphatase with peroxisomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each cellular organelle can be identified by its specific marker enzyme. Knowing these associations is essential for understanding cell biology and organelle function.

questions.text: The image below shows strangulation by Spanish windlass method. What type of strangulation method does it belong to? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Garroting

 

Spanish windlass

 

Method: It involves tightening an iron collar (Spanish windlass) around the neck and forcing a spike against the neck into the spinal cord.

 

Garroting- It involves attacking the victim by throwing the ligature from behind over the victim's neck and then tightened by twisting with a lever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bansdola: A method of strangulation where a ligature is applied in a different manner, often using a stick or rod to twist and tighten the ligature.

 

Option C. Mugging: Refers to a method where the assailant uses their limbs, such as the crook of their elbow, to compress the neck.

 

Option D. Throttling: Throttling involves using hands to manually compress the neck, leading to asphyxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Spanish windlass method of strangulation, shown in the image, belongs to the category of garroting, which involves the use of a ligature tightened by a lever or similar mechanism.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes develops a UTI, which gets complicated with hypotension that is resistant to IV fluids. Which of the following antibiotics can be used? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Piperacillin-Tazobactam

 

The patient with diabetes has developed a urinary tract infection (UTI) complicated by hypotension resistant to IV fluids, indicating septic shock. In cases of septic shock, it is critical to start with empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics. These antibiotics are designed to cover a wide range of potential pathogens until the specific causative organism can be identified and targeted.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics suitable for such severe infections include:

 

  • Piperacillin-Tazobactam
  • Carbapenems like Meropenem or Imipenem
  • Certain third-generation cephalosporins like Ceftazidime

 

In this case, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is chosen because it is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers many of the common pathogens responsible for severe infections and septic shock. Although a combination of Meropenem with Vancomycin would be ideal, the given options do not include Meropenem. Therefore, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is the best choice among the provided options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin-Clavulanate: This antibiotic is generally not sufficient for treating severe infections or septic shock due to its narrower spectrum of activity compared to Piperacillin-Tazobactam.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: While Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, it is not as broad-spectrum as Ceftazidime and does not provide the same coverage needed for septic shock.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: This antibiotic is typically used for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections and is not effective for severe systemic infections or septic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of septic shock, especially in a patient with diabetes and complicated UTI, broad-spectrum antibiotics such as Piperacillin-Tazobactam are critical for empirical therapy.

choices.text: Upper part of right inferior lobe

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the lung is affected when there is aspiration in supine position?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Upper part of right inferior lobe

 

The upper part of the right inferior lobe is most prone to aspiration in the supine position. This is commonly observed in patients with decreased consciousness, such as alcoholics.

 

The posterior segment of the right superior lobe and the superior segment of the inferior lobes are the most common sites for aspiration in a recumbent patient.

 

The position of the patient affects where the aspirated contents settle due to gravity dependence. Aspiration while standing usually affects the inferior lobes. In the supine position, aspirated material tends to settle in the posterior segments of the lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lingula: Lingula is incorrect. Aspiration usually does not affect the lingula as it is part of the left lung.

 

Option C. Right superior lobe: Right superior lobe is incorrect. While aspiration may affect the superior lobe, the posterior segment of the right superior lobe is more commonly affected in supine aspiration, not the superior lobe as a whole.

 

Option D. Right middle lobe: Right middle lobe is incorrect. Aspiration generally affects the lower lobes more than the middle lobe in the supine position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the supine position, aspiration typically affects the upper part of the right inferior lobe and the posterior segment of the right superior lobe. This pattern is due to the gravitational distribution of aspirated material in a recumbent patient.

questions.text: Water has accumulated in a container from a malfunctioning septic system, and mosquito larvae are observed. Based on the provided larval image, which mosquito species is it likely to be? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Culex

 

Culex mosquito breeds in dirty water. The image shows a Culex larva with head suspended downwards at an angle to water surface and a siphon tube.

 

  • In Culex, siphon tube is long and narrow
  • In Aedes, it is short and broad
  • In Mansonia, larvae are attached through siphon tube to roots of aquatic plants
  • In Anopheles- No siphon tube but only apertures on 8thabdominal segment

 

Breeding Habitant

 

Anopheles → Sophisticated Mosquito; Breeds in clean water

 

Culex → Nuisance Mosquito; Breeds in dirty water

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following can be used to calculate the cardiac output?

 

  1. ECHO
  2. Ventilation-perfusion scan
  3. Thermodilution
  4. Fick's principle
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A, C, D

 

Fick principle, thermodilution, and ECHO are methods used to measure cardiac output.

 

Cardiac output is the volume of blood pumped by the heart per minute into the aorta. The average cardiac output is approximately 5 liters per minute. Various indirect methods are available to measure cardiac output:

 

  • Fick’s principle calculates cardiac output based on oxygen consumption by the lungs and the arteriovenous difference in oxygen content in the blood. The formula used is:
    • Cardiac output (L/min) = (O₂ absorbed per minute by lungs (mL/min)) / (Arteriovenous O₂ difference (mL/L of blood))
  • Thermodilution method involves infusing cold saline into the right atrium through a Swan-Ganz catheter. The pulmonary artery temperature change is measured, and the temperature drop inversely correlates with the cardiac output.
  • ECHO (Echocardiography) measures cardiac output using ultrasound waves to assess blood flow velocity through the heart, particularly the left ventricle. Stroke volume and heart rate are used to calculate the cardiac output via this formula:
    • Cardiac Output = Stroke Volume × Heart Rate

 

Option A (ECHO): ECHO is correct but by itself is not the only method to calculate cardiac output.

 

Option B (Ventilation-perfusion scan): Incorrect. This scan assesses pulmonary circulation, not cardiac output.

 

Option C (Thermodilution): Correct, but not the only method to calculate cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Ventilation-perfusion scan is not used to measure cardiac output. It is primarily used to evaluate pulmonary circulation and assess conditions like pulmonary embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac output can be measured using several methods such as the Fick principle, thermodilution, and ECHO. The average cardiac output in adults is approximately 5 L/min.

questions.text: Which of the following option is a common size of a Foley catheter used in female patients and patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14 Fr

 

14 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 14 Fr are commonly used in adult female patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6 Fr: 6 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 6 Fr are commonly used in pediatric patients or in adults with narrow urethras. They are also used in urodynamic studies to measure bladder pressures.

 

Option C. 16 Fr: 16 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 16 Fr are commonly used in adult male patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Option D. 22 Fr: 22 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 22 Fr are commonly used in patients for suprapubic cystostomy. They are also used in patients who have undergone prostate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FOLEY’S CATHETER

 

The size in French (12F, 14F, 16F etc.) represents the outer diameter. 1 F = 1/3rd mm.

questions.text: Finasteride is used to treat male-pattern baldness by inhibiting which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5-alpha reductase

 

Finasteride is used to treat male pattern baldness by inhibiting 5-alpha reductase.

 

Finasteride is a competitive inhibitor of the 5-alpha-reductase enzyme, which inhibits the conversion of testosterone into its more active form, dihydrotestosterone (DHT). DHT is a key factor in the development of male pattern baldness. By inhibiting type 2 5-alpha reductase, finasteride reduces the amount of DHT in the scalp, slowing hair loss and, in some cases, promoting hair regrowth. It is also used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) by reducing prostatic epithelial cell proliferation.

 

Important Points:

 

  • The therapeutic effects are usually noticeable after about 6 months of treatment.
  • New hair growth is lost once the treatment is discontinued, similar to minoxidil.
  • Adverse effects include decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, and ejaculation disorders.

 

Finasteride is teratogenic, meaning it can cause abnormalities in male fetuses. Pregnant women should not be exposed to finasteride due to the risk of genital malformations in male babies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aromatase: Aromatase is an enzyme that converts androgens into estrogens. Inhibition of aromatase is used in the treatment of estrogen-dependent breast cancers, not for male-pattern baldness.

 

Option B. 17-hydrolase: 17-hydrolase is involved in steroidogenesis, particularly in the production of cortisol and sex steroids. Inhibition of 17-hydrolase is not related to hair loss treatment.

 

Option D. Phosphodiesterase: Phosphodiesterase inhibitors are used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction (such as sildenafil) by increasing cyclic GMP levels, leading to smooth muscle relaxation in the penis. It is not involved in the treatment of male-pattern baldness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Finasteride works by inhibiting 5-alpha reductase, which blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a major factor in male-pattern baldness and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child brought to OPD with complaints of fever, erythematous rash, and bone pain. X-ray of the skull revealed multiple lytic lesions. Skin biopsy shows prominent nuclear grooves with eosinophils as in the image below. Immunohistochemistry is positive for S100, CD1a. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

The above history along with the histopathological image showing Langerhans cells (image A), CD1a and positive S100 positive, is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).

 

 

Other option:

 

Option A. Rosai Dorfman disease: Rosai Dorfman disease doesn’t show histiocytes. It presents with painless lymphadenopathy.

 

Option B. Kimura disease: Kimura disease presents with painless lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Juvenile Xanthogranuloma: Juvenile Xanthogranuloma shows multinucleated giant cells. It presents with papular lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is identified by a combination of clinical symptoms (such as bone pain, fever, and rash), characteristic histopathological features (nuclear grooves, eosinophils), and positive immunohistochemical markers (S100, CD1a). The presence of multiple lytic bone lesions, especially in the skull, is a key diagnostic clue.

questions.text:
Match the following cell types with their associated malignancy. 

 

  1. Popcorn cell
  2. Faggot cell
  3. Cerebriform nuclei
  4. Starry sky

 

  1. Acute promyelocytic leukemia
  2. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
  3. Burkitt lymphoma
  4. Sezary syndrome
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

The correct matches are as follows:

 

  • 1. Popcorn cell: b. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
    • Popcorn cells, also known as L&H cells, are seen in nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL). These cells are large, with lobulated nuclei that resemble popcorn.
  • 2. Faggot cell: a. Acute promyelocytic leukemia
    • Faggot cells are characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). These cells contain multiple Auer rods in their cytoplasm, giving a bundle-like appearance (faggots).
  • 3. Cerebriform nuclei: d. Sezary syndrome
    • Cerebriform nuclei are seen in Sezary syndrome, a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The nuclei have a characteristic folded appearance resembling the cerebral cortex.
  • 4. Starry sky: c. Burkitt lymphoma
    • The "starry sky" pattern is observed in Burkitt lymphoma. It refers to the appearance of macrophages (stars) scattered among a background of malignant lymphocytes (sky), due to rapid tumor turnover and apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1-a, 2-d, 3-c, 4-b: Incorrect. Popcorn cells are not seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia; they are associated with lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma. Similarly, faggot cells are seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia, not Sezary syndrome. Cerebriform nuclei are characteristic of Sezary syndrome, not Burkitt lymphoma.

 

Option C. 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c: Incorrect. While the match for the popcorn cell is correct, faggot cells are seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia, not Sezary syndrome. Cerebriform nuclei are associated with Sezary syndrome, not acute promyelocytic leukemia.

 

Option D. 1-a, 2-b, 3-d, 4-c: Incorrect. The popcorn cell is not associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia but with lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma. Similarly, faggot cells are seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia, not lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The student must memorize the key associations of specific cell types with their respective malignancies:

 

  • Popcorn cell: Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Faggot cell: Acute promyelocytic leukemia
  • Cerebriform nuclei: Sezary syndrome
  • Starry sky: Burkitt lymphoma

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers

questions.text: Urinary alkalinization will be most useful in toxicity of which of the following drugs? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspirin
 

Urinary alkalinization is a key treatment in aspirin toxicity. Aspirin (salicylate) is a weak acid, and alkalinizing the urine increases the ionization of salicylates. This ionization traps salicylates in the urine, preventing their reabsorption and enhancing their elimination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta blockers: Urinary alkalinization is not a standard treatment for beta blocker toxicity. Management of beta blocker overdose typically involves supportive care and, in severe cases, specific antidotes like glucagon or high-dose insulin.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Similar to beta blockers, urinary alkalinization is not a primary treatment for calcium channel blocker overdose. Treatment often includes calcium infusions, glucagon, and other supportive measures.

 

Option C. Acetaminophen: For acetaminophen toxicity, the antidote N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is used. Urinary alkalinization is not effective for acetaminophen overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urinary alkalinization is most useful in the treatment of aspirin (salicylate) toxicity because it increases the elimination of salicylates by trapping them in the urine through ionization. This method is not effective for beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, or acetaminophen toxicity.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion 

 

The presentation of a child with a type B tympanometry curve indicates the likelihood of serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy as the underlying cause.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grommet insertion: While this can relieve middle ear effusion, it does not address the underlying adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion: Similar to grommet insertion alone, this option does not address the root cause of adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option D. Myringotomy: This procedure involves making an incision in the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure or drain fluid but does not address the cause or provide a lasting solution like adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is the most appropriate management for a child presenting with serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy, addressing both the immediate symptoms and underlying cause.

questions.text:
Which of the following method of disinfection and sterilization can also kill spores? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Glutaraldehyde
  2. Ethylene oxide
  3. Pasteurization
  4. Ortho-phthalaldehyde
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

Glutaraldehyde, Ethylene oxide, and Ortho-phthalaldehyde are effective methods of disinfection and sterilization that can kill spores.

 

1. Glutaraldehyde: This chemical is a broad-spectrum microbicidal and sporicidal agent. It is known for its compatibility with a variety of medical instruments. However, it requires activation and produces irritant fumes, which are notable disadvantages. Despite these drawbacks, glutaraldehyde is commonly recommended for the disinfection of fibroscopes and respiratory equipment due to its efficacy against spores and other microorganisms.

 

2. ETO (Ethylene oxide) inactivates all microorganisms although bacterial spores (especially B. atrophaeus) are more resistant than other microorganisms. For this reason B. atrophaeus is the recommended biological indicator. ETO is used in healthcare facilities to sterilize critical items (and sometimes semicritical items) that are moisture or heat sensitive and cannot be sterilized by steam sterilization like syringes, needles, catheters, and gloves. Bacillus atrophaeus and Bacillus subtilis are used as sterilization control.

 

4. Ortho-phthalaldehyde: Similar to glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde is a broad-spectrum microbicidal and sporicidal agent. It does not require activation and does not produce irritating fumes, which are significant advantages. However, it is costly and can stain medical equipment. It is often used as an alternative to glutaraldehyde for disinfecting scopes.

 

Other Options

 

3. Pasteurization or pasteurization is a process of food preservation in which packaged and non-packaged foods (such as milk and fruit juices) are treated with mild heat, usually to less than 100 °C (212 °F), to eliminate pathogens and extend shelf life. It has no sporicidal activity and kills non-spore-forming bacteria like Mycobacteria, Brucella, and Salmonella. There are two methods-

 

  1. Holder method -  milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes. Coxiella burnetii is relatively heat resistant and may survive the holder method.
  2. Flash method - milk is heated at 72°C for 15-20 seconds followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A petechial rash is associated with all the following, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Roseola infantum

 

  • Roseola infantum, also known as exanthem subitum or sixth disease, is a common viral illness caused primarily by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) and sometimes by human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7). The disease typically affects young children. It is characterized by a high fever lasting for three to five days, which abruptly resolves and is followed by the appearance of a rash. The rash consists of small, rose-pink or red 2 mm to 5 mm papules and macules. A pale halo can occur around the macules and papules in some cases. The rash usually begins on the trunk and can spread to the neck, extremities, and face. It is typically nonpruritic, blanching, and can persist from one to two days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

In contrast, petechial rashes are small, pinpoint, red or purple spots caused by bleeding into the skin and are associated with the following diseases:

 

Option A. Zika Virus: Zika virus infection can cause a mild, dengue-like illness, which includes symptoms like fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. The rash can be maculopapular, and in some cases, petechiae can be observed.

 

 

Option C. Kyasanur Forest Disease: This is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic to South India. It is caused by the Kyasanur Forest disease virus (KFDV) and presents with high fever, headache, severe muscle pain, vomiting, gastrointestinal symptoms, and hemorrhagic manifestations, including petechiae.

 

 

Option D. West Nile Fever: This disease is caused by the West Nile virus, which is transmitted by mosquitoes. Symptoms can range from mild to severe, including fever, headache, body aches, skin rash, swollen lymph nodes, and in severe cases, neurological complications. Petechial rashes can occur in some cases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.

choices.text: Amniotic fluid volume
Daily fetal movement count

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of biophysical profile? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Daily fetal movement count

 

Explanation:

 

Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is not a component of the BPP. DFMC, often assessed using Cardiff’s count of 10, is a separate method for monitoring fetal movements.

 

  • The Biophysical Profile (BPP) is a comprehensive test used in the assessment of fetal wellbeing. It includes five components, which are scored using the Manning score:
    1. Non-stress test (NST)
    2. Amniotic fluid volume (AFV)
    3. Fetal movements
    4. Fetal tone
    5. Fetal breathing movements
  • A low Manning score is indicative of fetal hypoxia and may necessitate further clinical intervention.
  • Additionally, the Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes only two components:
    1. Non-stress test (NST)
    2. Amniotic fluid index (AFI)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Amniotic fluid volume: Amniotic fluid volume is a component of the BPP and helps assess the amount of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus.

 

Option B. Fetal tone: Fetal tone is another component of the BPP, assessing the baby's muscle tone.

 

Option D. Non-stress test: Non-stress test (NST) is part of the BPP and evaluates the fetal heart rate in response to fetal movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Biophysical Profile (BPP) consists of five components: NST, AFV, fetal movements, fetal tone, and fetal breathing movements. Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is not part of the BPP.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 342, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 122

questions.text:
A child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking. On examination, there is decreased air entry in the left lung. What would be the correct management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Bronchoscopy
  2. Computed tomography scan
  3. ICD insertion
  4. Chest x-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 4

 

A child presenting with a history of choking and decreased air entry in the left lung is highly suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the left bronchus. The correct management steps include:

 

1. Bronchoscopy: This is the gold standard for both the diagnosis and removal of the foreign body. Rigid bronchoscopy is typically performed by a specialist, such as an otolaryngologist or pulmonologist, to visualize and extract the foreign body.

 

4. Chest X-ray: This is an essential initial investigation to assess for the presence of a foreign body. Although many foreign bodies are radiolucent, secondary findings such as air trapping, obstructive emphysema, atelectasis, asymmetric hyperinflation, mediastinal shift, and consolidation can be indicative of foreign body aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

2. CT scan: While a CT scan has high sensitivity and specificity for detecting radiolucent foreign bodies, it is not routinely performed in this situation due to the high radiation exposure, especially in children.

 

3. ICD insertion: Insertion of an intercostal drain (ICD) is not indicated unless there is clinical evidence of pneumothorax or other complications that require it. A chest X-ray is essential before deciding on this intervention.

 

Clinical Approach:

 

  • A detailed history and physical examination are critical when a child presents with choking.
  • A chest X-ray should be performed to assess for secondary signs of foreign body aspiration.
  • Bronchoscopy should be conducted even if imaging is negative but clinical suspicion remains high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with suspected foreign body aspiration, a chest X-ray and bronchoscopy are the key steps for diagnosis and management. Bronchoscopy allows for both visualization and removal of the foreign body.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS for failed conservative management 5 years ago. Uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation were done during the previous FESS. A DNE done now shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroid irrigation and antihistamines

 

The history of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip with endoscopy findings of mucosal edema suggests the presence of acute rhinosinusitis. The next best management involves nasal steroid irrigation along with antihistamines to reduce the mucosal inflammation, congestion, and edema. Even though the patient underwent FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery) 5 years ago, the patent ostia indicate that the surgery was successful in creating drainage pathways, but inflammation persists.

 

Acute viral rhinosinusitis often leads to mucosal edema, which can obstruct the sinus ostia and impair mucociliary clearance, causing symptoms like headache, facial pain, and nasal congestion. Steroid irrigation and antihistamines are used to reduce this inflammation and promote drainage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat surgery: Repeat surgery is not indicated because the DNE (Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy) findings show patent ostia, indicating no structural blockage requiring surgical correction. Surgery is reserved for patients with failed medical management or irreversible anatomical issues.

 

Option B. Macrolides for 4 months: Macrolides (such as azithromycin) are not routinely used for long-term management of rhinosinusitis unless there is chronic bacterial infection or the patient shows signs of immune deficiency. In this case, no bacterial infection is present, and there are no signs of infection requiring antibiotics.

 

Option D. Biological therapy: Biological therapies (e.g., monoclonal antibodies) are considered in refractory chronic sinusitis with polyps, especially when associated with conditions like asthma. However, they are not standard treatments for uncomplicated rhinosinusitis with mucosal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal steroid irrigation and antihistamines are the next best step in the management of acute rhinosinusitis with mucosal edema and patent sinus ostia, especially in patients with previous sinus surgery. This approach reduces inflammation and edema to restore normal sinus drainage.

questions.text: Eonism can be defined as? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wearing clothes of opposite sex

 

  • Eonism /Transvestism involves wearing clothes of the opposite sex to derive pleasure.
  • Eonism is named for Charles Eon de Beaumont, a French political adventurer who died in 1810 after posing as a woman for many years.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Public display of genitalia – Exhibitionism, where an individual derives pleasure from exposing their genitals to others in public.

 

Option C. Seeing a male undressing: This can be a form of voyeurism, though it is not specifically defined as such. Voyeurism typically involves deriving pleasure from secretly observing others who are undressing or engaging in sexual activities.

 

Option D. Seeing a female undressing- Voyeurism, where an individual derives pleasure from observing females undressing.

 

Educational Objective

 

Eonism or transvestism is the act of wearing clothes of the opposite sex for pleasure, named after Charles Eon de Beaumont.

questions.text: A patient has presented for a routine eye evaluation. You have checked his visual acuity using Snellen's chart and found it to be 6/6. What is the minimum angle of resolution? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5 minutes of arc

 

The angle subtended for a patient with 6/6 vision is 5 minutes of arc.

 

Visual acuity is a measure of the spatial resolution of the eye or an estimation of its ability to discriminate between two points.

 

Snellen's chart consists of a series of letters arranged in lines, each diminishing in size. Each whole letter will subtend the angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point of the eye at the given distance.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum angle of resolution for someone with a visual acuity of 6/6 using a Snellen chart is 5 minutes of arc. This indicates the precise and detailed visual capability required to resolve fine details at a standard distance, a fundamental concept in understanding and assessing visual acuity in clinical settings.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male presents to your clinic after a dog bite earlier in the day. Physical examination reveals a 1.5 cm abrasion with some oozing. Given the nature of the wound and the potential interventions post-exposure, which combination of actions and descriptors best characterizes the appropriate management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Category 3 wound
  2. Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes
  3. Clean the wound with spirit
  4. Loose suturing of the wound with a proper dressing
  5. Equine immunoglobin is given at a dose of 40 IU/kg of body weight, twice
  6. Intra-dermal vaccine is administered on days 0, 3, 7, 28
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 6

 

The patient with a dog bite presented with an abrasion, which comes under category 3 wound.

 

The components of post–exposure prophylaxis are:

 

  1. Local treatment of wound
  2. Antibiotics and anti-tetanus measures
  3. Active immunization against rabies – if indicated
  4. Passive immunization with rabies immunoglobulin – if indicated
  5. Observe the animal for 10 days from the day of bite:
    • If healthy after 10 days: Discontinue post – exposure vaccination
    • If dies within observation period: complete PEP
    • If observation not possible: complete the post – exposure vaccination

 

Other Option: 

 

Statement 4 – Abrasion wound doesn’t require suturing

 

Statement 5 – Equine Rabies Ig at dose of 40 IU/kg should be given only once.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The hormone that does not play a role in the growth of the fetus is: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Growth hormone.

 

Fetal growth is a complex process regulated by various hormones, but growth hormone does not play a significant role in this process during fetal life. The primary hormones involved in fetal growth include insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Insulin: Insulin is crucial for fetal growth, especially during the third trimester. It plays a key role in promoting the storage of nutrients and the growth of fetal tissues, particularly adipose tissue and muscle.
  • Thyroxine: Fetal production of thyroxine begins around the 12th week of gestation. Thyroxine is vital for the development of the central nervous system and overall growth and differentiation of tissues.
  • Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids are essential towards the end of gestation, particularly for the maturation of organs such as the lungs, liver, and gastrointestinal tract. They help prepare the fetus for life outside the womb by stimulating the production of surfactant in the lungs and facilitating the maturation of other critical systems.
  • Growth Hormone: Unlike in postnatal life, where growth hormone is a key regulator of growth, its role in fetal growth is minimal. Fetal growth is largely driven by insulin and other growth factors rather than growth hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin and Option C. Thyroxine: Both are crucial for fetal growth, regulating tissue growth and differentiation, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Glucocorticoids: These hormones are essential for the maturation of fetal organs before birth, particularly in the liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, which is primarily regulated by insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

choices.text: To break AT bonds high Tm is required
To break GC bonds low Tm is required
To break AT bonds low Tm is required
AT bonds and GC bonds need the same TM
