Educational Objective: 

 

SSRIs during pregnancy are linked to multiple neonatal risks. They may increase the risk of cardiac birth defects, decreased gestational age, spontaneous abortion, decreased birth weight, suboptimal fetal growth, low APGAR scores, autism spectrum disorders, ADHD and persistent pulmonary hypertension (SSRIs and SNRIs).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 687-688

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of ventricular action potential in the correct order: (INICET Nov 2022)

 

  1. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels
  2. Repolarizing K+ currents
  3. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
  4. Transient outward flow of potassium
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C, D, A, B

 

The ventricular action potential is characterized by a sequence of changes in membrane potential and ionic currents. The correct sequence is as follows:

 

  1. C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels: This is the initial depolarization phase (Phase 0). When the membrane potential reaches the threshold, voltage-gated sodium channels open, leading to a rapid influx of Na+ ions and a sharp rise in membrane potential.
  2. D. Transient outward flow of potassium: This corresponds to Phase 1. Shortly after the peak of the action potential, transient outward K+ channels open, causing a brief efflux of K+ ions which results in a slight repolarization.
  3. A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels: This is Phase 2, the plateau phase. Voltage-gated L-type calcium channels open, allowing Ca2+ to enter the cell. The influx of Ca2+ is balanced by the efflux of K+ through delayed rectifier K+ channels, maintaining a plateau in the membrane potential.
  4. B. Repolarizing K+ currents: This is Phase 3. The Ca2+ channels close, but the delayed rectifier K+ channels remain open, leading to a net efflux of K+ and returning the membrane potential to its resting value.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for ventricular action potential is as follows:

 

C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels

D. Transient outward flow of potassium

A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels

B. Repolarizing K+ currents

questions.text: The instrument shown below is used for estimating for hemoglobin levels. What does it measure? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acid hematin

 

The instrument shown in the image is a Sahli’s Hemoglobinometer, which is used to estimate hemoglobin levels in the blood. The principle of this method is based on the conversion of hemoglobin into acid hematin.

 

PRINCIPLE OF SAHLI’S HEMOGLOBINOMETER

 

Blood is mixed with an acid solution so that hemoglobin is converted to brown-colored acid hematin. This is then diluted with water till the brown color matches that of the brown glass standard. The hemoglobin value is read directly from the scale.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sahli’s Hemoglobinometer estimates hemoglobin levels by converting hemoglobin into acid hematin, which is then compared to a color standard.

questions.text: Pick the mechanism of death in cold water drowning? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vagal inhibition

 

  • In cold water drowning cause of death is Cold shock response/ hydrocution / immersion syndrome.
  • It is a series of neurogenic cardio-respiratory responses caused by sudden immersion in cold water.
  • Death results from vagal inhibition of the heart, i.e., cardiac arrest occurring due to increased stimulation of the vagus nerve by
  • Sudden entry of water into the nasopharynx or larynx
  • Diving into the water in a manner that is suddenly strikes the abdomen
  • Sudden in-rush of cold water into the ears

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asphyxia: Common in other types of drowning but not the primary cause in cold water drowning.

 

Option B. Laryngeal spasm: Can contribute to asphyxia but is not the primary mechanism in cold water drowning.

 

Option D. Cardiac arrest: While cardiac arrest occurs, it is due to vagal inhibition, not directly from cold water exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cold water drowning, the primary cause of death is vagal inhibition, leading to cardiac arrest due to the sudden stimulation of the vagus nerve from cold water immersion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of complicated cataracts? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Krukenberg spindle

 

Krukenberg spindle is not a feature of complicated cataracts. The slit lamp examination in pigmentary glaucoma shows a pattern of pigment deposition on the back of the cornea-endothelium called Krukenberg spindles.

 

 

  • Complicated or secondary cataracts develop due to inflammatory or degenerative conditions of the lens or other parts of the eye.
  • Causes of these cataracts include iridocyclitis and ciliary body tumors which disturb the nutrition of the lens.
  • These cataracts present with a breadcrumb appearance and polychromatic luster.
  • Vision impairment occurs even in the early stages due to location of the cataract at the nodal point.
  • Inflammation of the posterior segment causes posterior subcapsular cataract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polychromatic lustre: This is a feature seen in complicated cataracts where the lens exhibits a colorful sheen, often described as having a "christmas tree" or polychromatic appearance, particularly noticeable under slit-lamp examination.

 

Option C. Occurs after uveitis: Uveitis, an inflammatory disease affecting the uveal tract of the eye, can lead to the development of complicated cataracts. Chronic inflammation can disrupt the lens, leading to cataract formation.

 

Option D. Breadcrumb appearance: This refers to the appearance of small opacities within the lens, resembling breadcrumbs, commonly seen in complicated cataracts due to intraocular inflammation or other degenerative changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Krukenberg spindle is a vertical, spindle-shaped deposit of pigment on the posterior surface of the cornea, commonly seen in pigmentary glaucoma. It results from the dispersion of pigment granules from the iris that adhere to the corneal endothelium.

choices.text: The earth to all leads is in the right leg.
Lead I: Positive pole to the right and negative pole towards the left.
Lead III: Positive pole on the left and negative pole towards the right.
Lead II: Positive pole on the right and negative pole towards the left.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the placement of ECG leads?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The earth to all leads is in the right leg.

 

The statement "The earth to all leads is in the right leg" is correct. In the ECG setup, the right leg (RL) lead acts as the neutral or ground lead, often referred to as the "earth," and is used to stabilize the recordings by providing a reference point for all leads.

 

Bipolar limb leads for ECG recording:

 

  • Lead I: Positive input (LA), Negative input (RA)
  • Lead II: Positive input (LL), Negative input (RA)
  • Lead III: Positive input (LL), Negative input (LA)

 

The correct arrangement ensures accurate detection of electrical activity across the limbs for proper ECG interpretation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lead I: Positive pole to the right and negative pole towards the left: This is incorrect. In Lead I, the positive pole is on the left arm (LA), and the negative pole is on the right arm (RA). The current travels from right to left across the chest.

 

Option C. Lead III: Positive pole on the left and negative pole towards the right: This is incorrect. In Lead III, the positive pole is on the left leg (LL), and the negative pole is on the left arm (LA). The current travels from the left arm down to the left leg.

 

Option D. Lead II: Positive pole on the right and negative pole towards the left: This is incorrect. In Lead II, the positive pole is on the left leg (LL), and the negative pole is on the right arm (RA). The current travels diagonally from the right arm down to the left leg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The right leg (RL) is used as the ground or neutral electrode in ECG lead placement, stabilizing the readings for the limb leads. Familiarity with the bipolar lead configuration is essential for correct ECG interpretation.

choices.text: E1, E2, E5
E6, E7
L1, L2

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the proteins of the virus act as oncogenes?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E6, E7

 

The image shows the life cycle of the human papilloma virus, and the E6 and E7 proteins act as oncogenes

 

 

  • HPV oncogenes E6 and E7 deregulate host cell cycle by binding and inactivating tumor suppressor genes p53 and pRb.
  • Binding of E6 gene to p53 causes degradation of p53.
  • E7 gene binds to pRb and disrupts the complex between pRb and E2F leading to uncontrolled proliferation. HPV, human papilloma virus.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

  • E6 and E7 proteins of HPV are the primary oncogenes responsible for the virus's ability to cause cancer. They do this by inactivating key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and pRb, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation.

questions.text: Treatment of open fracture of femur: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open reduction and external fixation 

 

OPEN FRACTURES

 

  • An open fracture occurs when the bone breaks through the skin. 
  • These typically result from high-energy injuries and are often associated with significant damage to the surrounding soft tissues and contamination of the wound. 
  • These injuries are classified into three types according to the Gustillo-Anderson Classification:

 

 

  • All open fractures are emergencies.
  • These injuries require immediate administration of antibiotics and irrigation and debridement of the wound. 
  • The goal of the treatment is to achieve fracture healing and to prevent wound infections and osteomyelitis. 
  • They are frequently associated with injuries to surrounding vessels and nerves, which must be addressed as well. 
  • When the wound is contaminated, an external fixator is initially used. 
  • Early coverage of the wound is important to avoid infection. 
  • Immediately debride the wound of contaminated and devitalized tissue, copiously irrigate, and repeat debridement within 24-72 hours (Delayed wound closure is preferable).
  • Type and method of fixation:

 

 

  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin –Ilizarov fixator.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Closed reduction and internal fixation: Closed reduction is not done for an open fracture. An open fracture inherently involves a break in the skin and contamination. It requires surgical exploration, debridement, and irrigation of the wound in the operating room. Attempting a closed reduction would significantly increase the risk of deep infection (osteomyelitis). Internal fixation (e.g., with an intramedullary nail) can be used for less severe open fractures (Gustilo-Anderson Type I, II, and sometimes IIIA), after thorough open debridement. However, the combination with closed reduction makes this option incorrect for an open fracture.

 

Option D. Closed reduction and external fixation: Closed reduction is incorrect for an open fracture due to the necessity of open wound management. External fixation is a valid and often preferred method of stabilization for open fractures, particularly severe ones or as a temporary measure. However, the initial phase must involve open management of the wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The open fractures are best treated with open reduction and external fixation with the use of external fixators like ilizarov fixator.

choices.text: ER +, PR +, HER2 –
ER +, PR -, HER2 –
ER -, PR -, HER2 –
ER -, PR -, HER2 +

questions.text: What finding on immunohistochemical staining is consistent with basal-like breast cancer in a 59-year-old female presenting with a breast lump?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ER-, PR-, HER2-

 

ER -, PR -, HER2 –: Basal-like breast cancer is characterized by being negative for estrogen receptor (ER -), progesterone receptor (PR -), and HER2 (HER2 –). This profile is consistent with basal-like breast cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ER +, PR +, HER2 –: This profile indicates that the tumor is estrogen receptor-positive (ER +) and progesterone receptor-positive (PR +) but HER2-negative (HER2 –). This profile is not consistent with basal-like breast cancer.

 

Option B. ER +, PR -, HER2 –: This profile suggests that the tumor is estrogen receptor-positive (ER +) but progesterone receptor-negative (PR -) and HER2-negative (HER2 –). This is not consistent with basal-like breast cancer.

 

Option D. ER -, PR -, HER2 +: This profile indicates that the tumor is negative for estrogen receptor (ER -) and progesterone receptor (PR -) but HER2-positive (HER2 +). This profile is not consistent with basal-like breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal-like or triple-negative breast cancer is characterized by the absence of estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) on immunohistochemical staining. Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-coloured tissue, with ER and PR staining the nucleus brown, while HER2 staining the cell membrane brown.

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker presented with vague abdominal pain. On USG, he was found to have a renal mass lesion. CECT was done, as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal angiomyolipoma

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image presented here shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive angiomyolipoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma): Typically appears as a solid renal mass that may enhance heterogeneously after contrast administration and generally does not contain macroscopic fat.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: A benign renal tumor that typically appears as a well-circumscribed, homogeneously enhancing mass on imaging, without the characteristic fat component seen in angiomyolipomas.

 

Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled, round structure with no enhancement; the lesion in the image is solid with fatty components, inconsistent with a simple cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A female patient presents to the AIIMS emergency department with severe fatigue and prostration. She is a known case of chronic stable angina. While collecting a blood sample, you notice the blood has a brownish hue. What is the underlying diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Methemoglobinemia

 

The patient presenting with a brownish hue in the blood, coupled with a history of chronic stable angina, points towards methemoglobinemia. Patients with chronic stable angina are often on nitrate therapy, which is a known risk factor for developing methemoglobinemia.

 

Methemoglobinemia occurs when the iron in hemoglobin is oxidized from the ferrous (Fe²⁺) state to the ferric (Fe³⁺) state, which is unable to bind oxygen effectively. This results in reduced oxygen delivery to tissues, leading to symptoms such as fatigue and cyanosis. The brownish hue of the blood, often described as chocolate-colored, is characteristic of methemoglobinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carboxyhemoglobinemia: Carboxyhemoglobinemia is caused by carbon monoxide poisoning, typically associated with exposure to fire or automobile exhaust. The blood in this condition has a cherry red color, not brownish.

 

Option B. Sideroblastic anemia: Sideroblastic anemia is a form of anemia where the bone marrow produces ringed sideroblasts rather than healthy red blood cells. It does not cause a brownish hue in the blood.

 

Option D. Sulfhemoglobinemia: Sulfhemoglobinemia results from the incorporation of sulfur into hemoglobin, leading to a greenish or bluish color of the blood, rather than brownish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A brownish hue in the blood, especially in a patient on nitrate therapy, is indicative of methemoglobinemia, a condition where hemoglobin is oxidized, impairing its ability to carry oxygen effectively.

questions.text: A surgically resected specimen of an ovarian mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mature cystic teratoma

 

The specimen shows an ovarian mass with a tuft of hair in a cystic space, which is characteristic of a mature cystic teratoma. Key points about mature cystic teratomas include:

 

  • Teratomas are germ cell tumors: They contain various types of tissues derived from the three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
  • Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts): Typically unilocular and contain sebaceous material, hair, and sometimes other tissues such as teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and neural tissues.
  • Presentation: Most patients are asymptomatic, but they may present with an abdominal mass, acute pain due to torsion of the ovary, or rarely due to rupture of the cyst.
  • Treatment: Laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy is the treatment of choice for mature teratomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immature teratoma: These are malignant and contain immature embryonic tissues, often neuroectodermal. They usually occur in younger patients and are more aggressive.

 

Option C. Mucinous cystadenoma: A benign epithelial tumor of the ovary that typically contains mucinous material and does not contain hair or other tissues.

 

Option D. Serous cystadenoma: A benign epithelial tumor of the ovary that typically contains clear serous fluid and lacks the complex tissues found in teratomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mature cystic teratomas (dermoid cysts) are characterized by the presence of multiple tissue types such as hair, sebaceous material, and sometimes teeth or bone within a cystic ovarian mass.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about sympathetic, parasympathetic, and motor nerves. Which of the following statements are true? 

 

  1. Sympathetic efferents are distributed all over the body/ extensively whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited.
  2. Sympathetic fibers travel long distances after leaving the sympathetic chain, before finally synapsing and then a shorter distance to effector organs.
  3. Parasympathetic fibers travel a shorter distance to their respective ganglia which are located close to the target organs.
  4. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4

 

The true statements are 1 and 4.

 

  1. Sympathetic efferents are distributed extensively all over the body, whereas parasympathetic distribution is limited to the head, neck, and trunk regions.
  2. Sympathetic fibers travel short distances to the sympathetic ganglionic chain, before finally synapsing and then have a long course to supply the target organs. Parasympathetic fibers travel a longer distance to their respective ganglia, which are located close to the target organs.
  3. Motor neurons are located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord from where the axons come out and divide into several branches, each of which supplies an individual muscle fiber. A motor unit comprises a motor neuron and a group of skeletal muscle fibers it innervates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (1,3) is incorrect because Statement 3 is wrong. Parasympathetic fibers travel longer distances to their respective ganglia.

 

Option C (2,3) is incorrect because Statement 3 is wrong, and Statement 2 inaccurately describes sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D (2,4) is incorrect because Statement 2 is incorrect as sympathetic fibers travel shorter distances to ganglia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sympathetic nervous system has an extensive distribution throughout the body, while the parasympathetic nervous system has a limited distribution. Motor neurons located in the ventral horn of the spinal cord supply individual muscle fibers.

questions.text: A gentleman presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a past history of cough, on/off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with pale granuloma. His chest x-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleate giant cells, and caseous necrosis. What would be the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

In a patient with saddle nose deformity, septal perforation with pale granuloma and caseous necrosis on biopsy is consistent with tuberculosis (TB). The history of fever, cough, and hemoptysis along with cavitary lesions on chest x-ray supports the diagnosis of TB.

 

While other conditions like Wegener's granulomatosis (Option A), syphilis (Option C), and sarcoidosis (Option D) can also cause saddle nose deformity, the caseous necrosis on biopsy makes TB a more likely diagnosis.

 

Saddle-nose deformity refers to a depressed nasal dorsum that can involve either the bony, cartilaginous, or both components.

 

The most common cause is nasal trauma resulting in depressed fractures. Other causes include excessive submucosal resection, destruction of septal cartilage due to hematoma or abscess, and infections such as leprosy, tuberculosis, or syphilis, as well as inflammatory conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis) and sarcoidosis.

 

Chronic granulomatous conditions such as lupus, tuberculosis, and leprosy can affect the cartilaginous part, syphilis primarily affects the bony part, and Wegener's granulomatosis and T-cell lymphoma can lead to total (bony and cartilaginous) septal destruction involving both the bony and cartilaginous portions.

 

TB is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and primarily affects the lungs but can also involve the nose and sinuses.

 

Common symptoms of TB include fever, productive cough, weight loss, night sweats, and hemoptysis. Chest x-ray often shows multiple cavitation lesions affecting the upper lobe and hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy findings in tuberculosis typically reveal granulomas, caseous necrosis, and multinucleate giant cells (Langhan's giant cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener's granulomatosis: This can cause saddle-nose deformity and cavitary lesions, but biopsy would show necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis rather than caseous necrosis, which is seen in tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Syphilis can cause saddle-nose deformity, but typically affects the bony part of the nose, and biopsy would reveal gumma formation rather than the caseous necrosis seen in tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis can cause granulomas but lacks the caseous necrosis typically associated with tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Saddle-nose deformity with granuloma and caseous necrosis on biopsy is highly suggestive of tuberculosis.

choices.text: Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG
Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan

questions.text: 50-year-old obese female presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. The physician suspects acute cholecystitis and orders imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is not true about acute cholecystitis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan.

 

This statement is not true. In a Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid (HIDA) scan, the gallbladder is not preferentially visualized in acute cholecystitis. Instead, one of the hallmark findings in acute cholecystitis on a HIDA scan is non-visualization of the gallbladder due to inflammation and obstruction of the cystic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG: This statement is true and is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. On ultrasound (USG), a thickened gallbladder wall, typically greater than 3 mm, is indicative of inflammation and is a characteristic feature of acute cholecystitis.

 

Option B. Murphy's sign positive: This statement is true. Murphy's sign is a clinical maneuver used to assess for acute cholecystitis. It involves palpation of the right upper quadrant during inspiration, and if the patient experiences pain or stops breathing due to pain during this maneuver, it is considered a positive Murphy's sign, suggesting inflammation of the gallbladder.

 

Option C. Leukocytosis: This statement is true. Acute cholecystitis is associated with an inflammatory response, leading to an elevation in white blood cell count, which is known as leukocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute cholecystitis is a common condition characterized by inflammation of the gallbladder, typically due to the presence of gallstones obstructing the cystic duct. Clinical features of acute cholecystitis include right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. A positive Murphy's sign is right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation. On ultrasound imaging, gall bladder thickness >3 mm is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. The HIDA scan is a diagnostic tool for acute cholecystitis, showing non-visualization of the gall bladder 3 hours after radioisotope administration. Preferential visualization of the gall bladder on a HIDA scan is not a feature of acute cholecystitis. It is important to diagnose and treat acute cholecystitis promptly to prevent complications such as gallbladder perforation or gangrene.

questions.text: A clinician is examining various approaches to determine the rate at which a contraceptive method fails. Which index is specifically employed for this purpose? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pearl index

 

  • Pearl index is the common method used to measure contraceptive failure rate.
  • It is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY). This rate is given by the formula:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharmacological index: This term is generally refers to the study and categorization of drugs based on their effects and properties.

 

Option C. Performance index: This may refer to various metrics used to evaluate the performance of processes or systems in different fields.

 

Option D. Efficacy index: While this might be used to measure the effectiveness of a treatment or intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Pearl Index is the standard measure used to determine the contraceptive failure rate, defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure.
  • This index helps in evaluating the reliability and effectiveness of various contraceptive methods

questions.text:
An elderly patient on a vegetarian diet presenting with easy fatigability and pallor was investigated. Peripheral smear showed findings of macrocytic anemia. What is the probable cause of anemia in this patient? Other lab findings are as follows:

 

  • Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL
  • Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): 112 fL
  • Serum homocysteine: Elevated
  • Serum methylmalonic acid: Normal
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Folate deficiency

 

The most probable cause of anemia in this patient is folate deficiency. The clinical scenario of macrocytic anemia in a vegetarian patient with elevated homocysteine levels points to megaloblastic anemia. Megaloblastic anemia can be caused by either vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. However, normal methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels in this case suggest folate deficiency as the cause.

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency is usually associated with elevated MMA levels, which are absent here, further supporting folate deficiency as the correct diagnosis.

 

Folate deficiency is associated with the following laboratory findings:

 

  • Increased MCV (macrocytosis)
  • Elevated homocysteine levels
  • Normal MMA levels
  • Decreased reticulocyte count

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alcohol-induced macrocytosis: Although alcohol can cause macrocytosis, it is typically associated with chronic alcohol use. The patient’s history of being on a vegetarian diet and elevated homocysteine levels point away from this as the cause.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12 deficiency: This is a possible cause of macrocytic anemia. However, vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with elevated both homocysteine and methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels. The patient’s normal MMA level makes this option unlikely.

 

Option D. Thiamine deficiency: Thiamine deficiency is primarily associated with neurological issues (e.g., Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome) and is not known to cause macrocytic anemia. Therefore, this is not the correct cause of anemia in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of macrocytic anemia with elevated homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels, folate deficiency should be suspected. In contrast, both elevated homocysteine and MMA levels suggest vitamin B12 deficiency.

choices.text: Cry of baby in the womb
Infection of vagina
Infection of uterus
Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.text: What is vagitus uterinus? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cry of baby in the womb

 

  • Vagitus uterinus is the term used to describe the cry of a baby in the womb. It is a rare phenomenon but can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry, allowing the baby to make crying sounds while still in utero.
  • Vagitus vaginus is the term for the cry of the baby in the vagina, which can be heard during delivery.
  • Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis.
  • Infection of the uterus may affect its layers, leading to conditions such as endometritis (infection of the endometrium), myometritis (infection of the myometrium), and perimetritis (infection of the perimetrium).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infection of vagina: Infection of the vagina causes vaginitis, which is not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option C. Infection of uterus: Infection of the uterus can lead to endometritis, myometritis, or perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Option D. Infection of both vagina and uterus: Infection of both the vagina and uterus involves conditions such as vaginitis and endometritis/myometritis/perimetritis, which are not related to the term vagitus uterinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vagitus uterinus refers to the cry of a baby in the womb, which is a rare phenomenon that can occur if there is a rupture of the amniotic sac with air entry.

questions.text: Which of the following physiological adaptations is generally not observed at high altitudes? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis

 

The physiological adaptation that does not happen at high altitudes is respiratory acidosis. Respiratory alkalosis is the physiological adaptation seen at high altitudes due to hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary vasoconstriction: Correct, as it is a physiological response to low oxygen levels to improve gas exchange.

 

Option B. Polycythemia: Correct, as it increases the blood's oxygen-carrying capacity.

 

Option D. Hypoxia: Correct, as it is the primary condition caused by low oxygen levels at high altitudes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The principal means by which acclimatization to high altitude comes about are

 

  1. A great increase in pulmonary ventilation - increase in pulmonary ventilation on rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of carbon dioxide, reducing the Pco2 and increasing the ph of the body fluids.
  2. Increased numbers of red blood cells,
  3. Increased diffusing capacity of the lungs,
  4. Increased vascularity of the peripheral tissues
  5. Increased ability of the tissue cells to use oxygen despite low Po2.
  6. Cellular Acclimatization - cell mitochondria and cellular oxidative enzyme systems are slightly more plentiful than in sea-level inhabitants

choices.text: Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD20
Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD50
Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD20
Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD50

questions.text: Rituximab is a:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD20

 

Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that acts against CD20 B-cell antigen, which is expressed on the surface of B-lymphocytes, plasma cells, and certain B-cell lymphomas.

 

By binding to CD20, rituximab promotes apoptosis through transmembrane signaling and enhances antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) as well as complement-dependent cytotoxicity (CDC). Rituximab is widely used in the treatment of various B-cell malignancies, including B-cell lymphoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). It can be used alone or in combination with chemotherapy.

 

Adverse effects include infusion-related reactions such as chills, fever, urticaria, rashes, dyspnea, and hypotension. To mitigate these, pretreatment with antihistamines and corticosteroids is recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD20: Rituximab is not a polyclonal antibody. Polyclonal antibodies are derived from multiple B-cell clones and bind to various epitopes on the antigen. Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody, meaning it is derived from a single clone and binds specifically to one epitope on the CD20 antigen.

 

Option B. Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD50: Rituximab does not act against CD50, nor is it a polyclonal antibody. CD50 (ICAM-3) is involved in T-cell activation and leukocyte adhesion, not in B-cell lymphomas or chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

Option D. Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD50: Rituximab specifically targets CD20, not CD50. CD50 is associated with T-cell interactions, while rituximab is involved in targeting B-cell antigens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20 on B-cells, used in treating B-cell lymphomas and chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

questions.text:
Which of the following are signs of heart failure? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Non-pulsatile rise of JVP
  2. Orthopnea
  3. Dyspnea after 2 hours of sleep
  4. Right upper quadrant pain/Right hypochondrial pain
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4

 

Heart failure presents with a range of symptoms due to the inability of the heart to pump blood effectively. The following signs are indicative of heart failure:

 

  • Orthopnea (Option 2): This is difficulty breathing when lying flat and is a common symptom of left-sided heart failure.
  • Dyspnea after 2 hours of sleep (Option 3): Also known as paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND), this occurs due to fluid redistribution during sleep, leading to pulmonary congestion.
  • Right upper quadrant pain/Right hypochondrial pain (Option 4): This is associated with right-sided heart failure leading to congestive hepatomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 1 (Non-pulsatile rise of JVP): This is incorrect as heart failure typically causes a pulsatile rise in jugular venous pressure (JVP). A non-pulsatile rise in JVP is usually indicative of superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction, not heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Signs of heart failure include orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND), and right upper quadrant pain due to congestive hepatomegaly.

questions.text: Which hormone is secreted by placenta? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) hCG

 

Explanation:

 

  • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is the hormone secreted by the placenta. It is a glycoprotein produced by the syncytiotrophoblast cells of the placenta.
  • hCG can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8-9 days post-fertilization using radioimmunoassay. In early pregnancy, hCG concentrations in plasma double every 1.4-2 days.
  • The primary role of hCG is to maintain the corpus luteum during the beginning of pregnancy, ensuring the continued production of progesterone, which is critical for maintaining the uterine lining and supporting pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. LH: Luteinizing Hormone is produced by the anterior pituitary gland, not by the placenta. It plays a key role in regulating the menstrual cycle and ovulation.

 

Option C. FSH: Follicle-Stimulating Hormone is also produced by the anterior pituitary gland. It is involved in the development of ovarian follicles and the regulation of the menstrual cycle.

 

Option D. GnRH: Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone is produced by the hypothalamus, it stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to release FSH and LH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a hormone secreted by the placenta, crucial for maintaining early pregnancy by supporting the corpus luteum and progesterone production.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg266, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 66

choices.text: Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV
Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

questions.text: The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all of the following except?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV

 

Explanation:

 

The non-contraceptive benefits of combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) include:

 

  • Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer: COCPs reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.
  • Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer: COCPs lower the incidence of endometrial malignancy.
  • Reduction in the incidence of ectopic pregnancy: COCPs decrease the likelihood of ectopic pregnancies by preventing ovulation and thickening cervical mucus.

 

However, COCPs do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer: COCPs are known to reduce the incidence of ovarian cancer.

 

Option B. Ectopic pregnancy: COCPs lower the risk of ectopic pregnancy by preventing ovulation and thickening the cervical mucus.

 

Option D. Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer: COCPs decrease the risk of endometrial cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills do not provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 124, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 489

questions.text: Identify the pattern of abrasion shown in the image below? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ligature mark

 

A ligature mark is a well-known pressure mark on the neck underneath a ligature. It is a common injury in cases of hanging and strangulation.

 

Ligature Mark:

 

  • Appearance: Typically presents as a horizontal or slightly diagonal mark around the neck.
  • Cause: Caused by the application of a ligature (e.g., rope, cord, or similar object) under tension.
  • Context: Commonly associated with homicidal, suicidal, or accidental hanging and strangulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Graze abrasion: Caused by scraping or sliding friction against a rough surface, resulting in superficial loss of skin.

 

Option C. Brush burns: Result from friction burns, often appearing as red, inflamed, and abraded areas of skin.

 

Option D. Imprint abrasion: Caused by the impact of a patterned object, leaving an imprint on the skin.

 

Educational objective

 

Types of abrasions:

questions.text:
A healthcare worker in a remote primary healthcare clinic is reviewing the Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) on a vial of a vaccine that has been stored in the clinic for some time. Which of the following statements regarding the utility and interpretation of the VVM is/are correct?" (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. It is used for monitoring heat exposure of the vaccine by healthcare workers in primary healthcare.
  2. It shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat.
  3. It can be used to assess the potential efficacy of the vaccine.
  4. Calculation of the expiry date can be done using VVM.
  5. The expiry date of the vaccine can be relaxed if VVM is in an acceptable range.
  6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine can be safely used.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2

 

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.

 

Other Options:

 

3. A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.

 

4 & 5. Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.

 

6. If the square and the circle are the same in color, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 38-year-old civil engineer is working on a construction project in an area recently affected by a devastating earthquake. To prevent future devastation, the local government has amended the building codes. These changes are aimed at ensuring structures in the area can better withstand seismic activity. The engineer reviews the changes to determine the best approach for the new construction project. This modification to the building codes is primarily an example of which phase of disaster management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Disaster mitigation

 

  • The measures that are taken to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are part of disaster mitigation.
  • Mitigation involves measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing an emergency or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. In most cases mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system.

 

In Disaster Cycle, the steps involved are –

 

  1. Disaster Impact and Response: it involves search, rescue, first aid of the patients, triaging them according to the severity of their injuries and their likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention, tagging and identification of dead.
  2. Relief Phase or Disaster Containment by prompt assistance, epidemiological surveillance and disease control, vaccination, nutritional support.
  3. Rehabilitation involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions. It takes into account assessment and restoration of water supply, food safety and supply, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, vector control.
  4. Disaster Mitigation involves measures aimed at reducing or preventing the hazards from causing any emergency or to dampen the effects of emergencies. It involves flood mitigation works, appropriate land-use planning, improved building codes and reduction or protection of vulnerable population and structures.
  5. Disaster Preparedness is a long-term programme of developmental activities which aims at strengthening the overall capacity and capability of the country to efficiently and effectively manage all the emergencies.  

 

   

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disaster mitigation involves proactive measures such as improved building codes to reduce the impact of future disasters, aiming to lessen vulnerability and enhance resilience against potential hazards.

questions.text: A child presented with difficulty in walking. The wrist radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rickets

 

RICKETS

 

  • Osteoid matrix is secreted at normal rate but the mineralization is decreased (i.e. decrease in mineral apposition rate).
  • This leads to increased osteoid maturation time (mineralization).
  • Osteoid is increased in thickness, volume and total surface area.
  • Bone tissue throughout skeleton is incompletely calcified and therefore softened.
  • Rickets refers to condition where it occurs before closure of growth plates so that abnormalities of skeletal growth are superimposed.
  • Pathology:
    • Osteoid is laid down irregularly with widened osteoid seams and osteoid islets may even persist down into the diaphysis.
    • The new trabeculae are thin and weak (as bundle of collagen fibers instead of running parallel to Haversian canal, coarse perpendicularly) and with joint loading, the juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and ‘cup-shaped'.
  • Clinical features:
    • Generalized muscular hypotonia of an unknown mechanism is observed in most patients with clinical (as opposed to biochemical and radiographic) signs of rickets.
    • Craniotabes (areas of thinning and softening of bones of the skull) manifests early in infants with vitamin D deficiency, although this feature may not be present in infants, especially those born prematurely.
    • If rickets occurs at a later age, thickening of the skull develops. This produces frontal bossing and delays the closure of the anterior fontanelle.
    • In the long bones, laying down of uncalcified osteoid at the metaphyses leads to spreading of those areas, producing knobby deformity, which is visualized on radiography as cupping and flaring of the metaphyses.

 

 

  • Weight bearing produces deformities such as bow-legs and knock-knees.
  • In the chest, knobby deformities result in the so-called rachitic rosary along the costochondral junctions. The weakened ribs pulled by muscles also produce flaring over the diaphragm, which is known as Harrison groove. The sternum may be pulled into a pigeon-breast deformity.

 

 

  • In more severe instances in children older than 2 years, vertebral softening leads to kyphoscoliosis. The ends of the long bones demonstrate the same knobby thickening.
  • At the ankle, palpation of the tibial malleolus gives the impression of a double epiphysis (Marfan sign).

 

 

  • Because the softened long bones may bend, they may fracture on one side of the cortex (i.e., greenstick fracture).

 

  • X-rays:
    • Metaphyseal fraying and splaying along with cupping, thickening and widening of growth plate.
    • Bowing of legs and deformities occur at later stages.
  • Investigations:
    • Serum calcium, phosphate, 25-OH vitamin D are reduced.
    • Increased ALP and diminished urinary excretion of calcium.
  • Treatment:
  • Treatment with vitamin D (400-1000 IU per day) and calcium supplements are usually effective.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Osteomalacia. Often referred to as "soft bone disease," is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by the inadequate mineralization of bone tissue. There is adult onset of bone softening and muscle weakness. This condition results from a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, weakening and softening bones. Symptoms are non-specific and may include low back and thigh pain, proximal muscle weakness and wasting; Myalgia and arthralgia; Muscle spasms; waddling gait; Spinal, limb, or pelvic deformities; Aching bone pain aggravated by activity and weight-bearing; Increased falls; Hypocalcemic seizures or tetany. Triradiate pelvis, protrusion acetabular (acetabulum protrudes into pelvis due to bone softening. When bilateral, it is called as Otto Pelvis), pseudofracture are seen on x-ray. There is waddling gait due to muscular weakness.

 

 

A. Triradiate pelvis; B. Protrusio acetabuli

 

Option B. Osteogenesis imperfecta. It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative and qualitative defect in type I collagen formation. There is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen. Most common cause of multiple fractures in childhood. It is inherited from a parent in autosomal dominant (AD) fashion, or may occur as spontaneous mutation, or, rarely as autosomal recessive (AR) trait. The defining clinical feature is osteopenia, causing repeated propensity to fracture, generally after minor trauma and often without much pain or swelling. According to the severity of disease, fractures may occur in uterus, at birth, or after birth prior to or after walking age. Lower limb fractures are more common than upper limb. Femur is commonest bone fractured followed by tibia. Hyperlaxity of ligaments, with resultant hypermobility of joint is common. Blue/gray sclera due to uveal pigment visible through thin collagen layer. Deafness due to otosclerosis/pressure on auditory nerve. Dentinogenesis imperfect/crumbling of teeth i.e., deciduous and permanent teeth break easily and become prone to carries. Lower incisors severely affected. Skin becomes thin and translucent. Muscles are hypotonic due to multiple fractures and deformities. Wormian bones (detached portions of primary ossification centers of adjacent membrane bones) are seen in skull X-ray. Ring-shaped epiphysis is seen. Skeleton: White crumpled-bone shaped not maintained.

 

 

Option D. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity.

 

 

The diagnostic histological feature is irregular area of lamellar bone fitting together like a jigsaw with randomly distributed cement lines. It either occurs in one bone (monostotic) or multiple bones (polyostotic).

 

 

Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. Pain is most common presenting symptom. Limb looks bent and feels thick, and skin is unduly warm due to high vascularity. X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening, coarsening of trabecular markings and lytic and sclerotic changes. Blade of grass lesion is seen.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The image given in the question shows cupping, fraying and splaying of metaphysis of the distal end of both the radius and ulna, which are characteristic of rickets, alongwith walking difficulty.

questions.text: Which of the following is a gram-positive organism that shows the following appearance on Ziehl-Neelsen staining? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The characteristic morphology of Nocardia is a branching, filamentous, gram-positive rod when observed under the microscope. Nocardia can resemble Actinomyces species on gram stain.  However, Nocardia is an obligate aerobe that stains weakly positive on acid-fast staining.

 

Nocardia is typically weakly acid-fast after traditional carbol-fuchsin staining and positive on modified acid-fast staining due to the presence of mycolic acid in the cell wall. Unlike mycobacteria (also acid-fast positive), Nocardia has a “beaded” appearance on acid-fast staining. Nocardia is catalase-positive and urease positive.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacilli are acid fast but non-branching

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae bacilli are less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus; therefore, 10% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution.

 

 

Option D. Actinomyces are gram-positive but non-acid-fast in contrast to Nocardia.

 

The following image shows the filamentous gram-positive stained actinomyces:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia can be identified by its branching filamentous structure on gram stain and weak acid-fast positivity due to the presence of mycolic acid in its cell wall, distinguishing it from other gram-positive and acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: First deformity corrected in CTEV is:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cavus

 

CLUB FOOT/CONGENITAL TALIPES EQUINO VARUS (CTEV)

 

  • Incidence: 1:1000 live births
  • M:F – 2.5:1
  • 50% are bilateral
  • In its most characteristic form, there are four elements of deformity – Equinus of ankle, inversion of foot, adduction of fore foot and medial rotation of tibia.

 

 

  • Conservative Management:

 

 

  • First cast in CTEV is applied in supination to correct cavus.
  • Subsequently in kites, one deformity is corrected at a time, adduction first then varus and then equinus (CAVE).
  • In ponsetti method, adduction and Varus are corrected simultaneously and Equinus is corrected at last.
  • Thus in Kites method, one deformity is corrected at a time but in ponsetti adduction and varus are corrected simultaneously, equinus is corrected at end in both.

 

 

Sequential correction

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Forefoot adduction. This is corrected after the correction of the cavus deformity of the foot. (CAVE)

 

Option C. Varus. This is corrected after the correction of cavus followed by forefoot adduction. (CAVE)

 

Option D. Equinus. This is corrected in the last because it is the most resistant deformity. (CAVE)

questions.text: Match the following drugs in Column A with their contraindications in Column B? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

 

  • Morphine is contraindicated in head injury due to the following reasons:
    • It causes miosis and in patients with head injury who are in a comatose state, the progress of the patient after giving drugs is assessed by pupillary reaction. So, if the pupil already remains constricted due to morphine, the assessment of progress cannot be done.
    • Morphine leads to respiratory depression and if in the patients with head injury, if the respiratory rate is already depressed, it will get aggravated.
    • Respiratory depression will lead to accumulation of CO2, leading to vasodilatation and increased intracranial pressure.
  • Amiodarone can cause QT prolongation and even precipitate Torsade de pointes.
  • Vigabatrin is contraindicated in pregnancy as it is teratogenic.
  • Estrogen preparations are known to increase the risk of thromboembolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Morphine is contraindicated in head injury due to its effects on pupil size and respiratory depression. Amiodarone is associated with QT prolongation and potential arrhythmias. Vigabatrin is teratogenic and contraindicated in pregnancy. Estrogen increases the risk of thromboembolic events.

questions.text: What is the site of drainage of the structure marked in green?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sphenoethmoidal recess

 

The marked structure in the given image is the sphenoid sinus, and it drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

The paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities within the skull bones. These sinuses are divided into two main groups:

 

  1. Anterior group:
    • These sinuses drain into the middle meatus (Option B) via a common drainage pathway known as the osteomeatal unit.
    • The anterior group includes:
      • Maxillary sinus (antrum of Highmore)
      • Frontal sinus
      • Anterior ethmoidal sinus
  2. Posterior group:
    • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: These open into the superior meatus (Option A).
    • Sphenoid sinus: This sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

The inferior meatus (Option C) contains the opening of the nasolacrimal duct, which is guarded by Hasner's valve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior meatus: The superior meatus receives drainage from the posterior ethmoidal sinuses, but it is not the correct location for the sphenoid sinus drainage.

 

Option B. Middle meatus: The middle meatus is the drainage site for the maxillary, frontal, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses, but not for the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option C. Inferior meatus: The inferior meatus is associated with the nasolacrimal duct, which drains tears from the eye into the nasal cavity. It is not related to the drainage of the sphenoid sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sphenoid sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is located above the superior concha. Understanding the drainage pathways of the paranasal sinuses is important in diagnosing and treating sinus infections and related conditions.

questions.text: The Epstein-Barr virus interacts with B cells via which of the following? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CD21

 

  • The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) primarily infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor on the cell surface. CD21, also known as complement receptor 2 (CR2), is a receptor for the C3d fragment of the complement system and serves as the entry point for EBV into B cells. This interaction facilitates the virus's ability to infect and establish latency within B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CD20: This is a protein expressed on the surface of all B cells and is involved in B cell activation and proliferation. It is not used by EBV for cell entry.

 

Option C. CD19: This is a surface protein that acts as a co-receptor in B cell receptor signaling, but it is not directly involved in EBV entry.

 

Option D. CD23: This is the low-affinity receptor for IgE and does not play a role in EBV infection of B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor, which is the primary entry point for the virus into these cells.

questions.text: Choose the correctly matched pairs regarding the drugs used in schizophrenia:(INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1,2,4

 

Schizophrenia is managed with antipsychotic drugs that act on various neurotransmitter systems. Understanding their mechanisms of action and effects is essential for appropriate treatment. Here's a detailed look at each pair:

 

1. D2 antagonism – Reduces positive symptoms:

  •  
  • True. Positive symptoms of schizophrenia, such as hallucinations and delusions, are primarily managed by blocking dopamine D2 receptors. Typical antipsychotics like haloperidol and chlorpromazine are potent D2 antagonists and effectively reduce these symptoms.

 

2. 5HT2A antagonism – Reduces negative symptoms:

  •  
  • True. Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., clozapine, olanzapine) act by blocking serotonin 5HT2A receptors. This action helps to improve both the positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia, with a significant impact on negative symptoms like social withdrawal and apathy.

 

4. Muscarinic receptor antagonism – Reduces extrapyramidal symptoms:

  •  
  • True. Antagonism of muscarinic receptors can help reduce extrapyramidal side effects (EPS) caused by D2 antagonism. Drugs like benztropine, which are anticholinergics, are used to manage EPS by balancing the cholinergic and dopaminergic activities in the brain.

 

Other Options

 

3. 5HT1A agonism – Weight loss:

 

    • False. The 5HT1A receptor agonism is not directly associated with weight loss. In fact, weight gain is a common side effect of many atypical antipsychotics, which act on multiple serotonin and dopamine receptors. The statement should be regarding 5HT2C antagonism, which is associated with weight gain, not loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antipsychotic drugs manage schizophrenia by targeting various neurotransmitter systems. D2 antagonism helps reduce positive symptoms, while 5HT2A antagonism improves negative symptoms. Muscarinic receptor antagonism can help mitigate extrapyramidal side effects. Misconceptions about receptor effects, such as 5HT1A agonism causing weight loss, need to be corrected.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a mass in the right kidney on a CECT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal cell carcinoma        

 

Explanation:

 

The case of an elderly man with a heterogeneous large renal mass in the CECT image suggests renal cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC often appears as a solid renal mass with areas of necrosis or hemorrhage that cause the heterogeneity in density seen on CT images. This type of cancer is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults and can present with various imaging appearances, but a large, irregular, and heterogeneous mass is highly suggestive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal angiomyolipoma: Typically appears as a well-circumscribed mass with a significant fat component, which should show negative Hounsfield units (HU) on CT, which is not evident in the presented image.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: Generally presents as a well-circumscribed, homogenous mass with a central scar. It does not typically appear as heterogeneous as RCC.

 

Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled structure with very well-defined borders and no solid components, which does not match the characteristics of the mass show

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Oculocephalic reflex assesses the integrity of which of the following cranial nerves? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1. III

2. IV

3. VI

4. VIII

5. VII
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 4

 

The oculocephalic reflex, also known as the doll's eye reflex, is a brainstem reflex useful test for evaluating the function of cranial nerves III, VI, and VIII to determine brainstem function and assess brain death.

 

  • It is elicited by the examiner rapidly rotating the patient's head and observing the resulting eye movements. The test is performed in both lateral directions, as well as during flexion and extension of the neck. 
  • The oculomotor (III) nerve receives input from the vestibular (VIII) and abducens (VI) nerves, which relay signals to the brainstem nuclei responsible for generating conjugate eye movements. 
  • In a normal reflex, the eyes move in the opposite direction of head movement to maintain their orientation in space.

 

A negative reflex can indicate cranial nerve palsies or brainstem damage if the eyes do not move or move in the same direction as head movement. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oculocephalic reflex assesses the integrity of cranial nerves III (oculomotor), VI (abducens), and VIII (vestibulocochlear), which are crucial for coordinated eye movements in response to head motion.

questions.text: Which of the following primary second messengers is involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles while focusing on near objects?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IP3

 

IP₃ (inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate) is the primary second messenger involved in the contraction of ciliary muscles when focusing on near objects.

 

When focusing on a near object, the parasympathetic nerve fibers are stimulated, leading to the contraction of bilateral ciliary muscles via short ciliary nerves. This contraction relaxes the lens ligaments, thickening the lens and increasing its refractive power to help focus on a near object. This physiological process is known as the accommodation reflex.

 

The contraction of ciliary muscles is mediated through M₃ receptors (muscarinic receptors), and the parasympathetic signaling pathway activates the IP₃-DAG (diacylglycerol) cascade. This leads to the release of intracellular calcium (Ca²⁺), which in turn causes contraction of the ciliary smooth muscle, allowing accommodation.

 

Thus, the contraction of the ciliary muscles during near focusing is driven by IP₃ as the second messenger, via the parasympathetic nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cAMP: This second messenger typically mediates relaxation, not contraction, of smooth muscles. It works via the β-adrenergic receptors, which would lead to relaxation of ciliary muscles.

 

Option B. cGMP: This messenger is more associated with the nitric oxide pathway and vascular smooth muscle relaxation rather than ciliary muscle contraction.

 

Option C. Na+ inflow through a channel: Sodium ions (Na⁺) do not directly function as a primary second messenger in ciliary muscle contraction. They are involved in generating action potentials but not in the intracellular signaling pathways for muscle contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The second messenger inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate (IP₃) plays a crucial role in ciliary muscle contraction during the accommodation reflex, particularly when focusing on near objects. This mechanism involves parasympathetic stimulation of M₃ receptors and the subsequent increase in intracellular calcium.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of keratoconus? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haab's striae  

 

Haab’s striae are not a feature of Keratoconus. Haab's striae are seen in buphthalmos where the intraocular pressure is raised and the eyeball is enlarged as a whole. The enlarged cornea is associated with tears in Descemet's membrane called Haab's striae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Munson's sign: Directly associated with keratoconus. It is observed when the patient looks down, causing the lower eyelid to bulge out due to the cone-shaped cornea.

 

Option C. Irregular Astigmatism: A hallmark of keratoconus, resulting from the irregular thinning and bulging of the cornea.

 

Option D. Scissoring Reflex: This is a characteristic finding in keratoconus observed during retinoscopy due to the irregular shape of the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following signs may be elicited in keratoconus –

questions.text: Which of the following protein deficiency is responsible for Hereditary Angioedema? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C1 inhibitor  

 

Hereditary angioedema (HAE) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). The condition is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of the C1 inhibitor protein. C1 inhibitor is crucial in regulating the complement system, particularly the classical pathway, by inhibiting the activity of C1 esterase. In the absence or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor, uncontrolled activation of the complement pathway occurs, leading to excessive production of bradykinin, a potent vasodilator that causes the symptoms of angioedema.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Decay accelerating factor: Also known as CD55, this protein is responsible for regulating the complement system on cell surfaces, preventing damage to host cells. Deficiency of CD55 is associated with Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH), not hereditary angioedema.

 

Option C. CD59: This protein is also involved in the regulation of the complement system by inhibiting the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC). Like CD55, CD59 deficiency is associated with Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH), not hereditary angioedema.

 

Option D. C5 convertase: This is an enzyme complex that plays a role in the complement cascade by cleaving C5 into C5a and C5b, leading to the formation of the membrane attack complex. Deficiencies in components of C5 convertase can lead to increased susceptibility to infections, particularly with Neisseria species, but it is not associated with hereditary angioedema.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient with diabetes, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease has elevated serum creatinine and urea levels. Which of the following oral hypoglycemic agents is safe to use? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Linagliptin

 

Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) require careful selection of hypoglycemic agents due to altered drug excretion and the risk of further renal impairment. Among the given options, linagliptin is the safest choice for such patients. Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that does not require dose adjustment in patients with renal impairment, including those on hemodialysis. This is because linagliptin is primarily excreted via the liver rather than the kidneys.

 

Note – Certain GLP-1 receptor agonists like liraglutide, dulaglutide, and semaglutide can be used without dose adjustment according to the latest studies. Additionally, pioglitazone can also be used without dose adjustment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glimepiride: This sulfonylurea can cause hypoglycemia and requires dose adjustment in patients with renal impairment, making it less suitable for those with elevated serum creatinine and urea levels.

 

Option B. Exenatide: This GLP-1 receptor agonist is contraindicated in patients with severe renal impairment (creatinine clearance <30 mL/min) due to the risk of accumulation and potential toxicity.

 

Option C. Vildagliptin: Another DPP-4 inhibitor, vildagliptin requires dose adjustment in renal impairment, making it less favorable compared to linagliptin for patients with CKD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linagliptin is the preferred oral hypoglycemic agent for patients with diabetes and chronic kidney disease, as it does not require dose adjustment and is safely excreted by the liver.

questions.text: Identify the postmortem change given in the image below? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Marbling

 

  • The picture above shows a postmortem change called Marbling.
  • In marbling, blood vessels are visible on the skin as greenish-black streaks and eventually results in skin discoloration ranging from green to black, due to the formation of sulphmethemoglobin, which starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tattooing: Refers to punctate abrasions from unburned gunpowder particles, seen in gunshot wounds, not related to postmortem changes.

 

Option C. Lividity: Also known as livor mortis, this refers to the settling of blood in dependent parts of the body, causing a purplish-red discoloration.

 

Option D. Filigree burns: Caused by electrical burns, producing a lace-like pattern on the skin.

 

Educational objective

 

Marbling is characterized by the appearance of greenish-black streaks on the skin due to the formation of sulfmethemoglobin, typically becoming prominent 24-48 hours postmortem.

choices.text: Phosphatidyl glycerol and inositol phosphate

questions.text: A patient with erectile dysfunction is given sildenafil. Which of the following mediates the action of sildenafil? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. cGMP

 

  • Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitor.
  • The corpus cavernosum produces nitric oxide during arousal that stimulates the formation of cGMP. cGMP causes relaxation of the smooth muscle of the corpus cavernosum and penile arteries, engorgement of the corpus cavernosum, and erection.
  • By inhibiting PDE 5, the hydrolysis if cGMP is prevented, thus leading to erection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cAMP: cAMP (cyclic adenosine monophosphate) is another second messenger involved in various biological processes, but it is not the primary mediator in the mechanism of action of sildenafil for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Calcium: Calcium plays a critical role in muscle contraction and various cellular functions, but it is not directly involved in the mechanism of action of sildenafil for treating erectile dysfunction.

 

Option D. Phosphatidyl glycerol and inositol phosphate: These molecules are involved in different signaling pathways, such as the phosphatidylinositol pathway, but they are not relevant to the action of sildenafil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sildenafil, a PDE5 inhibitor, enhances and prolongs erections by preventing the breakdown of cGMP, which is the primary mediator responsible for smooth muscle relaxation and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis during arousal.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is caused by the defect of which of the following organelles?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peroxisomes

 

Zellweger syndrome is a peroxisome biogenesis disorder caused by defects in peroxisomes. Peroxisomes are essential organelles involved in various metabolic processes, and their dysfunction leads to Zellweger syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria: Zellweger syndrome is not caused by a defect in mitochondria. Mitochondria are responsible for energy production in cells, and defects in mitochondria lead to different diseases, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option B. Lysosomes: Zellweger syndrome is not caused by a defect in lysosomes. Lysosomes are responsible for breaking down cellular waste and are associated with lysosomal storage disorders, which are different from peroxisomal disorders like Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Nucleus: Zellweger syndrome is not primarily caused by a defect in the nucleus. It is a peroxisomal disorder, and the genetic mutations associated with Zellweger syndrome typically affect genes related to peroxisome biogenesis, not nuclear genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Zellweger syndrome, there are empty peroxisomes in all body cells causing defect in alpha-oxidation and oxidation of VLCFA. So, both phytanic acid and VLCFA accumulate. It is the most severe Peroxisomal Biogenesis Disorder (PBD).

questions.text: Sameer was tried in a court in the case of Sanjay’s murder in the park. Sahil appeared in court and stated that he saw Sameer with an axe in his hand while passing the park. What is this evidence known as? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Indirect

 

This type of evidence in known as an indirect evidence or circumstantial evidence.

 

This evidence providing only a basis for inference about the fact in dispute and it is not an eyewitness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hostile: Refers to a witness who is antagonistic or adverse to the party who called them to testify.

 

Option C. Direct: Evidence that directly proves a fact, such as an eyewitness account of the crime being committed.

 

Option D. Hearsay: Evidence based on what someone else said, not on the direct knowledge of the witness, and typically inadmissible in court due to its second-hand nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indirect or circumstantial evidence suggests a fact but does not directly prove it. In this case, seeing Sameer with an axe near the park suggests involvement but does not directly prove his guilt.

questions.text: Match the following:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

1-b: Colour vision - Ishihara chart:

 

Colour vision is tested with Ishihara plates, which is a pseudoisochromatic chart. There are patterns of coloured and grey dots that reveal one pattern to persons with normal colour vision and another to those with the colour deficiency.

 

The below image shows a representative plate of the Ishihara chart.

 

 

Limitation of ischihara chart: Ischihara chart is useful as a screening tool for colour blindness. It mainly tests for red-green blindness.

 

In order to check blue-yellow blindness other tests such as 100 Hue Test are required.

 

2-a: Intraocular pressure - Applanation tonometer:

 

An applanation tonometer is used to measure the intraocular pressure. It is based on the Imbert-Fick law, which states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening (A).

 

P = W/A

 

The following is an image of the applanation tonometer:

 

 

There are two types of applanation tonometers:

 

(1) In which the surface area of the prism is constant – Eg

 

  1. Goldmann Applanation Tonometer (GAT):
    • The Goldmann tonometer is one of the most widely used and considered the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure.
    • It consists of a prism that is gently applied to the anesthetized cornea, flattening a small area.
    • The amount of force required to flatten the cornea is directly related to intraocular pressure.
  2. Perkins Applanation Tonometer:
    • The Perkins tonometer is a handheld, portable device used for measuring intraocular pressure.
    • It is similar in principle to the Goldmann tonometer but is more compact and easier to transport.
  3. Tono-Pen (Reichert Tonometer):
    • The Tono-Pen is a handheld electronic applanation tonometer.
    • It works by measuring the force required to flatten the cornea, and the reading is displayed electronically.
    • It is often used in clinical settings due to its ease of use and portability.

 

(2) Tonometer with constant pressure and variable area – eg. MALAKOFF’S Tonometer.

 

3-d: Peripheral vision - Perimetry:

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic procedure used to chart the boundaries of a person's visual field. There are two main types of perimetry: kinetic and static perimetry. Kinetic perimetry involves moving a target with a specific luminance from a non-seeing area in the periphery towards the center until the person perceives it. In contrast, static perimetry involves presenting a stationary stimulus and adjusting its intensity until the person either reaches a threshold of detection or can no longer detect it. One type of static perimetry is tangent screen perimetry, which tests the central 30 degrees field at 1 meter and evaluates a person's central vision.

 

Examples of Kinetic Perimetry – Goldmann perimetry and Bjerrum Perimetry

 

Examples of Static Perimetry – Static Automated perimetry – Humphrey Visual Field analyser and Octopus Visual field analyser.

 

4-c: Central vision - Tangent screen test:

 

The tangent screen test is a specific method used to assess central visual field up to 30 degrees from fixation. It involves using a black screen and white or colored targets to determine the sensitivity of central vision, particularly useful in detecting central visual field defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Colour vision - Ishihara chart
  • Intraocular pressure - Applanation tonometer
  • Peripheral vision - Perimetry
  • Central vision - Tangent screen test

questions.text: Hooch tragedy is related to which of the following alcohols?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methyl alcohol

 

Option A. Methyl alcohol (Correct Answer): Hooch tragedies are typically associated with the consumption of illicit liquor that contains methanol. Methanol is toxic to the human body and can lead to serious health issues, including organ damage and even death, when consumed in significant amounts.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ethyl alcohol: Ethyl alcohol, also known as ethanol, is the type of alcohol commonly found in alcoholic beverages that are legally produced and regulated. It is not typically associated with hooch tragedies.

 

Option C. Ethylene glycol: Ethylene glycol is not related to hooch tragedies. It is a chemical compound used in products such as antifreeze and is highly toxic when ingested.

 

Option D. Hypoglycin: Hypoglycin is a naturally occurring toxin found in certain plants, such as the ackee fruit, and is not directly related to hooch tragedies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Country liquor can be categorised as spurious liquor or hooch when the amount of methane added could turn fatal. There are number of death cases reported every year due to consumption of such alcohol.

 

The metabolism of methyl alcohol is shown in figure below:

 

 

The formaldehyde and formic acid formed as products during the metabolism can cause severe metabolic acidosis, blindness and neurologic damage.

 

The treatment involves administration of ethanol or Fomepizole which act as competitive inhibitors of enzyme ADH and prevent the formation of these two products.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection? (INICET NOV 2022)
