Other options:

 

2. Inhibits T cells: This is incorrect. IL-12 actually activates T cells, particularly promoting the differentiation into Th1 cells, rather than inhibiting them.

 

3. Inhibits B cells: This is also incorrect. IL-12 does not inhibit B cells; instead, it indirectly influences B cell function by promoting a Th1 response, which supports cellular immunity over humoral (B cell) immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is produced by macrophages and increases the production of interferon- γ (IFN- γ).

questions.text: A hospital is investigating the effectiveness of statins in a multiple-centric clinical trial. The study involves 4000-5000 patients and half of them have received the drug while the other half was given a placebo. Both the subjects and the investigators are unaware of which group is getting the drug and which group is being administered the placebo. Which of the following phases of clinical trial corresponds to this scenario? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Phase 3  


As the study is being conducted in multiple centers in a double blinded manner, where neither the physician nor the patients know what they are receiving, therefore this trial is in Phase 3.

 

The phases of clinical trials are as follows: -

 

 

  • Phase Zero trials are called micro-dosing studies. It is an optional trial done by some companies on small number of healthy volunteers to know the pharmacokinetics of the drug. Dose used is one-hundredth of the final human dose or 100 microgram (whichever is lower).
  • Pre-clinical trials are animal studies. The drugs are first tested on the small animals like rats, guinea pig etc. to know the complete pharmacokinetics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The described clinical trial, with its large sample size, multiple centers, double-blind design, and focus on confirming the efficacy of statins, corresponds to a Phase 3 clinical trial. This phase is crucial for determining whether the drug is effective and safe for widespread use.

questions.text: A 16-year-old presents with absent menses. Examination shows widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and Tanner grade 1 breast development. USG shows streak ovaries. Investigation shows raised FSH, raised LH, and reduced estradiol. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

 

The patient's clinical features are strongly suggestive of Turner syndrome (45XO), a condition characterized by:

 

  • Widely spaced nipples: Shield chest appearance.
  • Webbed neck: Due to congenital lymphedema.
  • Tanner grade 1 breast development: Indicates no breast development.
  • Streak ovaries on ultrasound: Ovaries that are underdeveloped and nonfunctional.
  • Hormonal profile: Raised FSH and LH due to lack of negative feedback from the ovaries, and reduced estradiol indicating ovarian failure.

 

Other clinical features of Turner syndrome include short stature, primary amenorrhea, congenital heart defects, and renal anomalies. The syndrome results in hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kallmann syndrome: It is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia (lack of sense of smell), not hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Option C. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: 46XY karyotype with female external genitalia, well-developed breasts, absent axillary and pubic hair, and gonads are testes, not streak ovaries.

 

Option D. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome: Mullerian agenesis, where secondary sexual characters are present but the uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina are absent. This syndrome does not present with webbed neck or widely spaced nipples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by primary amenorrhea, streak ovaries, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, widely spaced nipples, and a webbed neck.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg411, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 441

questions.text:
A patient presented with ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensations in the face, vertigo with numbness and loss of sweating, and dysarthria on the contralateral side. All these symptoms are caused due to a lesion in:

 

  1. Medial medulla
  2. Lateral medulla
  3. Ventromedial medulla
  4. Lateral medulla including nucleus ambiguus and spinothalamic tract
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B and D

 

The clinical scenario describes lateral medullary syndrome or Wallenberg syndrome, which occurs due to an infarction in the lateral portion of the medulla, typically caused by occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery or vertebral artery. The neurological deficits described are consistent with damage to multiple structures in the lateral medulla.

 

Key features of lateral medullary syndrome include:

 

  • Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, anhidrosis) due to damage to descending sympathetic fibers.
  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the face due to involvement of the spinal trigeminal nucleus.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the body due to involvement of the spinothalamic tract.
  • Vertigo and ataxia due to involvement of the vestibular nuclei and inferior cerebellar peduncle.
  • Dysarthria and dysphagia due to involvement of the nucleus ambiguus, affecting cranial nerves IX and X.

 

This pattern of neurological deficits is specific to damage in the lateral medulla, including the nucleus ambiguus and spinothalamic tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral medulla: While this is partly correct, it doesn’t fully describe the involvement of the specific structures (like nucleus ambiguus) responsible for the dysphagia and dysarthria.

 

Option C. Ventromedial medulla: A lesion in this area would affect motor pathways, such as the corticospinal tract, leading to weakness or paralysis on the contralateral side, which is not described in this patient.

 

Option D. Medial medulla: Medial medullary syndrome would involve the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII), causing tongue deviation and contralateral hemiparesis, which is not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) is caused by an infarction in the lateral medulla, affecting structures such as the spinothalamic tract, nucleus ambiguus, trigeminal nucleus, and sympathetic fibers, leading to a distinct pattern of ipsilateral and contralateral deficits.

choices.text: Junction of thick descending limb and DCT
Junction of thick descending limb and PCT
Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT
Junction of DCT and collecting duct

questions.text: Macula densa is made of specialized cells located at:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT 


The macula densa consists of specialized cells located at the distal end of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, where it meets the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). These cells are part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus, which helps regulate blood pressure and filtration rate within the kidneys by monitoring sodium concentration in the filtrate. The macula densa responds to changes in sodium chloride concentration by signaling the juxtaglomerular cells to either increase or decrease renin release, thus impacting the glomerular filtration rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Junction of thick descending limb and DCT: Incorrect. The macula densa is not located at the junction of the thick descending limb of the loop of Henle and the DCT. The descending limb is involved in water reabsorption, and its function differs from that of the thick ascending limb.

 

Option B. Junction of thick descending limb and PCT: Incorrect. The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) is located at the start of the nephron, near the glomerulus, and does not meet the thick descending limb of the loop of Henle where the macula densa is located.

 

Option D. Junction of DCT and collecting duct: Incorrect. The distal convoluted tubule (DCT) connects to the collecting duct further downstream from the location of the macula densa. The macula densa is specifically positioned near the end of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

 

Educational Objective:


The macula densa is located at the junction of the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle and the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), and is an integral part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus responsible for regulating kidney function and blood pressure through the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases trabecular outflow?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Netarsudil

 

The drug that increases trabecular outflow is Netarsudil.

 

Netarsudil is a rho-kinase inhibitor used in the treatment and management of glaucoma and ocular hypertension. It lowers intraocular pressure (IOP) by directly relaxing the trabecular meshwork, thus increasing aqueous outflow. It also reduces aqueous humor production. Netarsudil is administered as an ophthalmic solution, typically one drop into the affected eye once daily in the evening. Adverse effects may include conjunctival hyperemia and corneal verticillata.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a non-selective β-blocker that reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous humor production through β-receptor blockade on the ciliary epithelium. Ocular side effects may include allergy, decreased corneal sensation, and punctate keratitis.

 

Option C. Brimonidine: Brimonidine is a selective alpha-2 agonist. It reduces aqueous synthesis and increases uveoscleral outflow. As it crosses the blood-brain barrier, it may cause drowsiness and CNS depression. It is contraindicated in infants and young children.

 

Option D. Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases IOP by reducing aqueous humor formation. It has a bitter taste upon administration and is contraindicated in individuals with sulfonamide allergies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Netarsudil is a rho-kinase inhibitor that increases trabecular outflow in the treatment of glaucoma and ocular hypertension by relaxing the trabecular meshwork.

questions.text:
A baby is diagnosed with B cell leukemia. All of the following are good prognostic factors except: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Hyperdiploidy
  2. Age < 1 year
  3. t(9;22)
  4. t(4;11)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4

 

B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) is a common type of leukemia in children. Prognostic factors play a crucial role in determining the treatment plan and overall outcomes for patients.

 

2. Age < 1 year: Age less than 1 year is considered a poor prognostic factor in B-ALL. Infants with B-ALL typically have a higher risk of relapse and a poorer response to therapy.

 

3. t(9;22): This translocation involves the Philadelphia chromosome, which is generally associated with poor prognosis in B-ALL. It leads to the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion protein, which is a marker of poor prognosis.

 

4. t(4;11): This translocation is associated with rearrangements of the MLL (Mixed-Lineage Leukemia) gene, which is a poor prognostic factor in B-ALL. It is commonly seen in infants and is associated with a poor outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Hyperdiploidy: Hyperdiploidy (>50 chromosomes) is actually a good prognostic factor in B-ALL. Children with hyperdiploid B-ALL generally have a better response to therapy and a higher overall survival rate.

 

Thus, the factors B (Age < 1 year), C (t(9;22)), and D (t(4;11)) are all poor prognostic indicators, and only A (Hyperdiploidy) is a good prognostic factor.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy was brought to OPD with complaint of fatigue. Serum investigations revealed findings as given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Hemoglobin – 9 g/dl

 

Mean cell volume (MCV) – 60 fL

 

Mean cell Hb (MCH) – 20 pg

 

Serum Ferritin – 185 mcg/L

 

Total leukocyte count – Elevated lymphocyte and Neutrophils

 

[Reference normal values for this question: Serum Ferritin: 50-200 mcg/L; Mean cell volume (MCV) - 80-100 fL; Mean cell Hb (MCH) - 27-31 pg]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thalassemia

 

The clinical presentation of fatigue, along with laboratory findings, strongly suggests thalassemia.

 

  • MCV of 60 fL and MCH of 20 pg are both very low, indicating microcytic hypochromic anemia, which is typical in thalassemia.
  • Serum ferritin is within the normal range (185 mcg/L), which rules out iron-deficiency anemia, as that condition would typically present with low ferritin levels.
  • The elevated lymphocyte and neutrophil counts could be a secondary response but are not specific to thalassemia.

 

Thalassemia is characterized by a reduction in the synthesis of globin chains (alpha or beta), leading to ineffective erythropoiesis and anemia. The microcytosis and hypochromia (low MCV and MCH) are hallmarks of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia of chronic disorder: Typically presents with normal to reduced MCV and low serum iron, but ferritin is usually raised, not within the normal range.

 

Option C. Iron-deficiency anemia: Would show low serum ferritin, low MCV, and low MCH, but the serum ferritin here is normal.

 

Option D. Sickle cell anemia: Would not typically present with low MCV and MCH, as sickle cells tend to be normocytic or macrocytic.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic
Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic
Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal transverse colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an extended right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be resected during an extended right colectomy to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic.

 

During an extended right colectomy, the ileocolic, right colic, and trunk of the middle colic vessels are typically resected to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma.

 

The stem of the middle colic and the left colic artery are not resected during an extended right colectomy as they are not directly involved with the blood supply to the proximal transverse colon. It is important to note that the surgical management of colon cancer depends on the stage and location of the tumor and may involve various surgical techniques, including colectomy and lymphadenectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of radical colectomies and vessels ligated:

 

  1. Right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and right branch of middle colic artery
  2. Extended right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and stem/origin of middle colic artery
  3. Left hemicolectomy: Left colic and sigmoid artery

questions.text: In which of the following is atropine contraindicated? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute congestive glaucoma

 

The use of atropine is not recommended in cases of acute congestive or angle closure glaucoma due to the risk of increasing intraocular pressure.

 

  • Since atropine is a mydriatic, it may lead to the obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris, causing a sudden increase in intraocular pressure.
  • Dim light can also precipitate an attack.
    • Atropine may be indicated as a cycloplegic agent to alleviate pain and prevent synechiae formation in corneal ulcers and acute anterior uveitis.
    • In malignant glaucoma, atropine can be the initial management option.
    • In corneal ulcers, atropine is used as an adjuvant therapy, to reduce pain induced by ciliary muscle spasm via its cycloplegic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute anterior uveitis: Atropine is actually beneficial in cases of acute anterior uveitis. It helps to relieve pain by paralyzing the ciliary muscle and preventing the formation of posterior synechiae (adhesions between the iris and the lens), which can complicate uveitis.

 

Option C. Malignant glaucoma: In malignant glaucoma, atropine might be used as part of the management strategy to try to break the attack by deepening the anterior chamber and pulling the lens-iris diaphragm backward.

 

Option D. Corneal ulcer: Atropine is used in the treatment of corneal ulcers to provide comfort by relieving the painful ciliary spasm and to prevent synechiae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine should be used cautiously, and is contraindicated in acute congestive glaucoma due to its potential to exacerbate the condition by further increasing intraocular pressure.

questions.text: Brunt sugar smell of urine is due to the defect of? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Explanation:

 

  • Burnt sugar-like odour is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase/decarboxylase.
  • It results in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine. There is also mental retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase leads to phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by a mousy or musty odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites.

 

Option B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase: Deficiency of isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase causes isovaleric acidemia, which is associated with a rancid, cheesy, or sweaty feet odor due to the accumulation of isovaleric acid.

 

Option C. Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase: Deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase leads to tyrosinemia type I, which is characterized by a boiled cabbage or rotten mushrooms odor due to the accumulation of tyrosine and its metabolites.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What does the provided formula correspond to? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Standard deviation

 

  • The formula given represents the standard deviation, which measures the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of values.
  • It is the square root of the variance, where the variance is the average of the squared differences from the mean.
  • Standard deviation: This is the deviation of each value from the standard value (mean). It provides insight into the spread of the data points around the mean.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variance = (Standard deviation)2. It represents the average of the squared deviations from the mean.

 

Option C. Mean is obtained as the sum of all values divided by the number of values. It is not affected by extreme values.

 

Option D. Median is the middle most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Standard deviation is the deviation of each value from the standard value [Mean].

questions.text: What is depicted in the following image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Babinski sign

 

The image depicts the Babinski sign, also known as the plantar reflex test, where the lateral aspect of the sole is stroked. In an abnormal or positive Babinski sign (as seen in upper motor neuron lesions), the great toe dorsiflexes, and the other toes fan out. This reflex is commonly tested to assess neurological function, particularly in conditions affecting the corticospinal tract.

 

The Babinski sign is normal in infants up to 2 years old due to the immaturity of the corticospinal pathways but is abnormal in older children and adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Withdrawal reflex: The withdrawal reflex is a protective reflex that causes an involuntary retraction of a body part from a painful stimulus. It does not involve the fanning of toes or dorsiflexion of the great toe.

 

Option C. Grasp reflex: The grasp reflex involves an involuntary flexing of the fingers or toes when the palm of the hand or sole of the foot is stimulated. It is seen in infants but is not the reflex being tested in this image.

 

Option D. Plantar reflex: The plantar reflex refers to the downward (plantar) flexion of the toes when the sole of the foot is stroked. This is the normal response in adults, but in this case, the image shows the abnormal response (Babinski sign).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Babinski sign involves dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of the other toes when the lateral aspect of the sole is stroked. This sign is abnormal in adults and older children, indicating an upper motor neuron lesion.

choices.text: There is hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus.
Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery
Supply is from posterior to anterior thoracic artery.
Collaterals develop to supply upper limb.

questions.text: A child presents with cold feet and a history of wearing socks even in the summers. On examination, lower limb pulses are diminished as compared to the radial pulse. Prominent radio femoral delay is present. What is the underlying condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery

 

The clinical presentation of cold feet, wearing socks even in summer, diminished lower limb pulses compared to radial pulses, and prominent radiofemoral delay is characteristic of coarctation of the aorta. This congenital condition is characterized by a narrowing (coarctation) of the aorta, typically just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery at the ductus arteriosus.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Coarctation of the Aorta: This condition results in the obstruction of blood flow, leading to higher blood pressure in the upper limbs and lower blood pressure in the lower limbs. The radiofemoral delay is a classic sign.
  • Location of Coarctation:
    • Postductal Coarctation (Adult Type): The constriction occurs distal to the ductus arteriosus. This type is more common and leads to the development of collateral circulation to bypass the obstruction.
    • Predductal Coarctation (Infantile Type): The constriction occurs proximal to the ductus arteriosus, leading to different clinical features and often presenting in infancy.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Cold feet and preference for wearing socks may be due to poor perfusion in the lower extremities.
    • Diminished lower limb pulses and radiofemoral delay are hallmark signs.
    • Hypertension in the upper extremities due to the coarctation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus: This condition does not cause radiofemoral delay or the constellation of symptoms seen in coarctation of the aorta.

 

Option C. Supply from posterior to anterior thoracic artery: This does not explain the clinical presentation, especially the radiofemoral delay.

 

Option D. Collaterals develop to supply upper limb: Collateral circulation is a compensatory mechanism that develops over time in coarctation of the aorta, primarily to supply blood to the lower extremities, not just the upper limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta typically presents with cold feet, diminished lower limb pulses, and radiofemoral delay due to a narrowing of the aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery.
